Plague	B-Disease
is	O
a	O
bacterial	O
disease	O
transmitted	O
to	O
humans	O
by	O
the	O
bite	O
of	O
an	O
infected	O
flea	O
,	O
or	O
by	O
handling	O
an	O
infected	O
animal	O
.	O

Taking	O
steps	O
to	O
avoid	O
flea	O
exposure	O
will	O
help	O
prevent	O
spread	O
of	O
the	O
disease	O
.	O

In	O
humans	O
,	O
the	O
symptoms	O
of	O
plague	B-Disease
infection	O
are	O
high	O
fever	O
,	O
chills	O
,	O
headache	O
,	O
extreme	O
fatigue	O
and	O
tender	O
or	O
swollen	O
lymph	O
glands	O
.	O

If	O
you	O
experience	O
these	O
symptoms	O
,	O
contact	O
your	O
physician	O
.	O

Plague	B-Disease
is	O
endemic	O
in	O
El	B-City
Paso	I-City
County	O
,	O
and	O
precautions	O
to	O
prevent	O
plague	O
should	O
always	O
be	O
taken	O
.	O

Paso	I-City
County	O
's	O
last	O

case	O

in	O
1991	O
;	O

as	O

.	O

from	O

for	O

last	O

.	O

The	O

,	O

11th	O

case	O

7	O

[	O

]	O

.	O

9-12	O
annually	O
before	O
that	O
.	O

In	O
a	O

on	O
the	O
mumps	B-Virus
outbreak	O
in	O
Toronto	B-City
,	O
city	O

officials	O
report	O
4	O
additional	O
cases	O
since	O
the	O
outbreak	O
was	O
1st	O
reported	O
approximately	O
one	O
week	O
ago	O
.	O

Currently	O
,	O
there	O
have	O
been	O
18	O
confirmed	O
cases	O
of	O
mumps	B-Virus
in	O
Toronto	B-City
in	O
2017	O
as	O
of	O
1	O
Mar	O
2017	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
Toronto	O
Public	O
Health	O
.	O

The	O
outbreak	O
is	O
primarily	O
affecting	O
young	O
adults	O
,	O
18	O
to	O
35	O
years	O
of	O
age	O
.	O

Earlier	O
reports	O
on	O
the	O
investigation	O
note	O
that	O
many	O
of	O
these	O
cases	O
have	O
frequented	O
bars	O
in	O
the	O
west	O
downtown	O
core	O
of	O
Toronto	B-City
.	O

The	O
mumps	B-Virus
virus	O
is	O
found	O
in	O
saliva	O
and	O
respiratory	O
droplets	O
.	O

It	O
is	O
spread	O
from	O
person	O
to	O
person	O
through	O
coughing	O
,	O
sneezing	O
,	O
and	O
coming	O
into	O
contact	O
with	O
a	O
person	O
's	O
saliva	O
by	O
sharing	O
drinks	O
or	O
utensils	O
,	O
food	O
or	O
water	O
bottles	O
,	O
or	O
by	O
kissing	O
.	O

A	O
major	O
factor	O
contributing	O
to	O
outbreaks	O
is	O
being	O
in	O
a	O
crowded	O
environment	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
attending	O
the	O
same	O
class	O
,	O
playing	O
on	O
the	O
same	O
sports	O
team	O
or	O
living	O
in	O
a	O
dormitory	O
with	O
a	O
person	O
who	O
has	O
the	O
mumps	B-Virus
.	O

The	O
chilli	O
crop	O
in	O
Nagpur	B-City
and	O
Amravati	B-City
is	O
reported	O
to	O
have	O
been	O
hit	O
by	O
a	O
virus	O
.	O

The	O
infection	O
may	O
bring	O
the	O
yield	O
down	O
by	O
almost	O
50	O
per	O
cent	O
.	O

Even	O
growers	O
in	O
Madhya	B-Province
Pradesh	I-Province
have	O
been	O
hit	O
,	O
where	O
the	O
crisis	O
is	O
reported	O
to	O
be	O
worse	O
[	O
and	O
]	O
the	O
crop	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
down	O
to	O
30	O
per	O
cent	O
.	O

This	O

in	O

.	O

[	O

]	O
,	O

.	O

is	O

.	O

.	O

between	O
its	O

.	O

,	O

15-19	O

.	O

are	O

the	O

of	O

.	O

Public	O
Health	O
France	B-Country
considers	O
it	O
necessary	O
to	O
prepare	O
for	O
an	O
outbreak	O
.	O

``	O
The	O
current	O
epidemiology	O
of	O
measles	B-Virus
shows	O
that	O
France	B-Country
is	O
still	O

and	O
is	O
not	O
immune	O
to	O
a	O
new	O
outbreak	O
of	O
significant	O
[	O
size	O
]	O
.	O
''	O

In	O
fact	O
,	O
the	O
[	O
cases	O
]	O
are	O
distributed	O
rather	O
evenly	O
in	O
the	O
territory	O
.	O

The	O
scenario	O
of	O
an	O
epidemic	O
is	O
all	O
the	O
more	O
credible	O
because	O
the	O

is	O
so	O
low	O
.	O

Only	O
79	O
percent	O
of	O
babies	O
2	O
years	O
old	O
are	O
vaccinated	O
.	O

It	O
would	O

to	O
reach	O
95	O
percent	O
in	O

to	O
prevent	O
any	O

of	O
the	O
virus	O
.	O

In	O

,	O

France	B-Country
recommends	O
that	O

.	O

If	O
the	O
[	O

series	O
]	O
is	O
incomplete	O
,	O
a	O

catch-up	O
or	O

will	O
prevent	O
the	O
spread	O
of	O
the	O
virus	O
.	O

The	O

:	O

2011	O
.	O

In	O
the	O
space	O
of	O
a	O

15	O

;	O

.	O

France	B-Country
is	O
[	O

alone	O
]	O

this	O

.	O

.	O

.	O

(	O

)	O
.	O

who	O

.	O

.	O

of	O
Dagestan	B-Province
.	O

in	O
Dagestan	B-Province
were	O

rabies	B-Virus
high-risk	O

in	O
2010	O
.	O

8	O

.	O

66.7	O

000	O

)	O
.	O

Health	O
officials	O
in	O
Mali	B-Country
recently	O
announced	O
that	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
a	O
resurgence	O
of	O
malaria	B-Disease
with	O
multiple	O
new	O

cases	O
throughout	O
the	O
region	O
.	O

There	O
has	O
been	O
a	O
sharp	O
rise	O
in	O
malaria	B-Disease
cases	O
located	O
in	O
Mali	B-Country
's	O
northern	O
areas	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
other	O
regions	O
during	O
the	O
last	O
few	O
weeks	O
.	O

To	O
support	O
the	O
Ministry	O
of	O
Health	O
in	O
Mali	B-Country
,	O
the	O
World	O
Health	O
Organization	O
(	O
WHO	O
)	O
,	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
its	O
health	O

,	O
have	O
provided	O
the	O
area	O
with	O
care	O
and	O
support	O
for	O
the	O
cases	O
that	O
have	O
been	O
confirmed	O
.	O

These	O
interventions	O
have	O
helped	O
mobile	O
clinics	O
located	O
throughout	O
Timbuktu	B-City
,	O
Gao	B-City
and	O
Kidal	B-City
[	O
regions	O
]	O
.	O

There	O
are	O
ongoing	O
investigations	O
to	O
discover	O
if	O
the	O
epidemic	O
threshold	O
has	O
been	O
attained	O
or	O
not	O
.	O

Every	O
year	O
,	O
health	O
officials	O
watch	O
a	O
resurgence	O
in	O
malaria	B-Disease
cases	O
during	O
Mali	B-Country
's	O
rainy	O
season	O
.	O

The	O
resurgence	O
of	O
the	O
illness	O
may	O
be	O
connected	O
to	O
the	O
rainy	O
season	O
,	O
especially	O
since	O
this	O
year	O
[	O
2015	O
]	O
has	O
had	O
irregularly	O
high	O
rainfall	O
.	O

This	O
has	O
resulted	O
in	O
stagnant	O
water	O
where	O
mosquitoes	O
can	O
breed	O
.	O

The	O
public	O
health	O
specialist	O
of	O
the	O
Ministry	O
of	O
Health	O
in	O
Western	O
Bahr	O
al-Ghazal	O
state	O
has	O
revealed	O
that	O
17	O
suspected	O
cases	O
of	O
anthrax	B-Disease
disease	O
in	O
humans	O
have	O
been	O
reported	O
in	O
the	O
state	O
.	O

Martin	O
Mayen	O
said	O
that	O
the	O
1st	O
2	O
suspected	O
cases	O
were	O
reported	O
in	O
February	O
2011	O
,	O
and	O
15	O
more	O
cases	O
were	O
reported	O
to	O
his	O
office	O
this	O
week	O
from	O
Mabior	O
Abiem	O
and	O
Nyin	O
Akok	O
of	O
Marial	O
Bay	O
Payam	O
.	O

Anthrax	B-Disease
is	O
a	O
bacterial	O
disease	O
that	O
primarily	O
affects	O
animals	O
but	O
can	O
be	O
transmitted	O
to	O
humans	O
through	O
consumption	O
of	O
infected	O
meat	O
or	O
contact	O
with	O
an	O
infected	O
carcass	O
.	O

Mayen	O
urged	O
people	O
not	O
to	O
eat	O
meat	O
from	O
any	O
animal	O
unless	O
they	O
know	O
how	O
it	O
died	O
,	O
and	O
how	O
long	O
it	O
has	O
been	O
dead	O
.	O

.	O

disease	O
called	O

(	O

)	O

of	O

[	O

region	O
]	O
.	O

,	O

from	O
SENASA	O
was	O

.	O

There	O
are	O
at	O
least	O
150	O
hectares	O
[	O
371	O

]	O
affected	O
recording	O
a	O

5	O

8	O

per	O

.	O

There	O
have	O
already	O
been	O
more	O
than	O
150	O
cases	O
of	O
whooping	B-Disease
cough	I-Disease
reported	O
in	O
Sydney	B-City
in	O
2016	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
bulk	O
of	O
these	O
have	O
come	O
from	O
suburbs	O
in	O
the	O
inner	O
west	O
.	O

The	O
Director	O
of	O
Public	O
Health	O
from	O
Sydney	B-City
Local	O
Health	O
District	O
,	O
Dr	O
Leena	O
Gupta	O
,	O
said	O
that	O
so	O
far	O
in	O
2016	O
,	O
the	O
local	O
government	O
areas	O
with	O
the	O
highest	O
number	O
of	O
incidences	O
have	O
been	O
Canterbury	B-City
(	O
35	O
)	O
,	O
Marrickville	B-City
(	O
26	O
)	O
,	O
Ashfield	B-City
(	O
23	O
)	O
and	O
Leichhardt	B-City
(	O
22	O
)	O
.	O

Primary	O
school	O
students	O
are	O
the	O
most	O
likely	O
to	O
be	O
affected	O
by	O
whooping	B-Disease
cough	I-Disease
(	O
also	O
known	O
as	O
pertussis	O
)	O
,	O
but	O
anyone	O
can	O
contract	O
it	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
can	O
be	O
life-threatening	O
for	O
infants	O
(	O
aged	O
6	O
months	O
and	O
under	O
)	O
.	O

Whooping	B-Disease
cough	I-Disease
usually	O
begins	O
like	O
a	O
cold	O
with	O
a	O
blocked	O
or	O
runny	O
nose	O
,	O
tiredness	O
,	O
mild	O
fever	O
and	O
a	O
cough	O
.	O

The	O
cough	O
gets	O
worse	O
,	O
and	O
severe	O
bouts	O
of	O
uncontrollable	O
coughing	O
can	O
develop	O
.	O

Coughing	O
bouts	O
can	O
be	O
followed	O
by	O
vomiting	O
,	O
choking	O
or	O
taking	O
a	O
big	O
gasping	O
breath	O
which	O
causes	O
a	O
whooping	O
sound	O
.	O

Gray	O
mould	O
,	O
caused	O
by	O
_Botrytis	O
cinerea_	O
,	O
is	O
among	O
the	O
most	O
serious	O
fungal	O
disease	O
of	O
table	O
grape	O
(	O
_Vitis	O
vinifera_	O
)	O
worldwide	O
.	O

This	O
pathogen	O
is	O
responsible	O
for	O
heavy	O
losses	O
in	O
Mazzarrone	B-City
,	O
among	O
the	O
most	O
important	O
Italian	O
areas	O
for	O
table	O
grape	O
production	O
.	O

From	O
2009	O
to	O
2013	O
,	O
scientists	O
collected	O
302	O
single-spore	O
isolates	O
of	O
_B	O
.	O

cinerea_	O
from	O
vineyards	O
in	O
[	O
the	O
]	O
district	O
[	O
and	O
]	O
evaluated	O
in	O
vitro	O
sensitivity	O
to	O
,	O
identified	O
point	O
mutations	O
in	O
field	O
isolates	O
resistant	O
to	O
different	O
fungicides	O
,	O
and	O
investigated	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
isolates	O
with	O
multiple	O
fungicide	O
resistance	O
.	O

45.7	O
per	O
cent	O
were	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
resistant	O
to	O
at	O
least	O
1	O
fungicide	O
.	O

About	O
10	O
per	O
cent	O
had	O
multiple	O
resistance	O
to	O
at	O
least	O
2	O
or	O
more	O
individual	O
fungicides	O
.	O

[	O
Some	O
]	O
isolates	O
[	O
showed	O
]	O
simultaneous	O
resistance	O
to	O
4	O
different	O
classes	O
of	O
fungicides	O
.	O

Accordingly	O
,	O
these	O
fungicides	O
failed	O
to	O
control	O
infections	O
by	O
isolates	O
with	O
resistance	O
or	O
reduced	O
sensitivity	O
.	O

This	O
study	O
represents	O
the	O
1st	O
report	O
of	O
_B	O
.	O

cinerea_	O
field	O
isolates	O
with	O
single	O
or	O
multiple	O
resistance	O
to	O
botryticides	O
.	O

By	O
continuous	O
selection	O
of	O
multi-resistant	O
isolates	O
,	O
chemical	O
control	O
of	O
gray	O
mould	O
in	O
vineyards	O
will	O
become	O
increasingly	O
difficult	O
.	O

Thus	O
,	O
careful	O
monitoring	O
of	O
sensitivity	O
and	O
multiple	O
resistance	O
to	O
botryticides	O
over	O
time	O
will	O
be	O
crucial	O
in	O
managing	O
fungicide	O
resistance	O
.	O

[	O
Fungicides	O
]	O
should	O
be	O
[	O
used	O
]	O
in	O
alternation	O
or	O
in	O
mixtures	O
with	O
different	O
[	O
modes	O
of	O
]	O
action	O
and	O
low	O
risk	O
of	O
resistance	O
development	O
.	O

CWD-positive	O
white-tailed	O
deer	O
found	O
on	O
Iowa	B-City
County	O
farm	O
Contact	O
:	O
Raechelle	O
Belli	O
,	O
608-224-5005	O
or	O
Bill	O
Cosh	O
,	O
Communications	O
Director	O
,	O
608-224-5020	O
A	O
white-tailed	O
deer	O
from	O
a	O
deer	O
farm	O
in	O
Iowa	O
County	O
has	O
tested	O
positive	O
for	O
chronic	B-Disease
wasting	I-Disease
disease	I-Disease
(	O
CWD	O
)	O
,	O
Wisconsin	B-Province
State	O
Veterinarian	O
Dr.	O
Paul	O
McGraw	O
announced	O
today	O
(	O
29	O
Jan	O
2016	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
National	O
Veterinary	O
Services	O
Laboratory	O
in	O
Ames	O
,	O
Iowa	B-City
,	O
confirmed	O
the	O
test	O
results	O
.	O

The	O
2-year-old	O
buck	O
,	O
which	O
was	O
born	O
on	O
the	O
farm	O
and	O
killed	O
after	O
sustaining	O
an	O
injury	O
,	O
was	O
among	O
only	O
15	O
deer	O
reported	O
to	O
be	O
on	O
the	O
1-acre	O
farm	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
farm	O
's	O
June	O
2015	O
registration	O
.	O

The	O
owner	O
keeps	O
a	O
small	O
number	O
of	O
deer	O
for	O
public	O
exhibition	O
only	O
and	O
does	O
not	O
move	O
the	O
deer	O
anywhere	O
except	O
to	O
slaughter	O
.	O

All	O
of	O
the	O
owner	O
's	O
deer	O
that	O
have	O
died	O
or	O
been	O
sent	O
to	O
slaughter	O
since	O
2002	O
have	O
been	O
tested	O
for	O
CWD	O
.	O

Samples	O
were	O
taken	O
from	O
the	O
buck	O
on	O
9	O
Jan	O
2016	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Wisconsin	B-Province
Department	O
of	O
Agriculture	O
,	O
Trade	O
and	O
Consumer	O
Protection	O
's	O
(	O
DATCP	O
's	O
)	O
rules	O
,	O
which	O
require	O
testing	O
of	O
farm-raised	O
deer	O
and	O
elk	O
when	O
they	O
die	O
or	O
are	O
killed	O
.	O

The	O
farm	O
has	O
been	O
quarantined	O
since	O
2008	O
,	O
when	O
wild	O
deer	O
within	O
a	O
5-mile	O
radius	O
were	O
diagnosed	O
with	O
CWD	O
.	O

The	O
DATCP	O
Animal	O
Health	O
Division	O
's	O
investigation	O
will	O
also	O
examine	O
the	O
animal	O
's	O
history	O
and	O
trace	O
movements	O
of	O
deer	O
onto	O
the	O
property	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
any	O
other	O
deer	O
farms	O
may	O
have	O
exposure	O
to	O
CWD	O
.	O

A	O
wild	O
duck	O
has	O
been	O
found	O
positive	O
for	O
HPAI	B-Disease
H5N8	I-Disease
in	O
the	O
municipality	O
of	O
Osterwald	B-City
in	O
the	O
German	O
county	O
Bentheim	O
,	O
25	O
km	O
[	O
15.53	O
mi	O
]	O
from	O
the	O
Dutch	O
city	O
Almelo	O
.	O

The	O
Friedrich-Löffler	O
Institute	O
(	O
FLI	O
)	O
has	O
confirmed	O
the	O
infection	O
officially	O
on	O
.	O

The	O
finding	O
has	O
come	O
to	O
light	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
the	O
German	O
Wild	O
Bird	O
Monitoring	O
Program	O
.	O

There	O
are	O
no	O

farms	O
in	O
a	O
3	O
km	O
[	O
1.86	O
mi	O
]	O
radius	O
around	O
the	O
site	O
.	O

No	O

area	O
has	O
been	O
set	O
.	O

The	O
site	O
is	O
adjacent	O
to	O
the	O
[	O
district	O
]	O
Twente	O
,	O
[	O
within	O
the	O
]	O
province	O
of	O
Overijssel	O
.	O

According	O
to	O
Avined	O
,	O
the	O
infection	O
clearly	O
shows	O
that	O
the	O
avian	O
flu	O

is	O
present	O
in	O

and	O
that	O
strict	O

remains	O
necessary	O
.	O

The	O
California	B-Province
Department	O
of	O
Food	O
and	O
Agriculture	O
(	O
CDFA	O
)	O
has	O
confirmed	O
the	O
1st	O
case	O
of	O
West	B-Virus
Nile	I-Virus
virus	I-Disease
(	O

)	O
in	O
a	O
horse	O
in	O
2012	O
,	O
according	O
to	O

on	O

organization	O
's	O
website	O
.	O

``	O
On	O
26	O
Jul	O
2012	O
,	O
the	O
CDFA	O
Animal	O
Health	O
Branch	O
confirmed	O
the	O
1st	O
positive	O
equine	O
West	B-Virus
Nile	I-Virus
virus	I-Disease
case	O
in	O
Stanislaus	B-City
County	O
,	O
''	O
the	O
statement	O
read	O
.	O

``	O
The	O
2-year-old	O
unvaccinated	O
filly	O
displaying	O
severe	O
neurologic	O
signs	O
was	O
euthanized	O
.	O
''	O

In	O
a	O
blog	O
post	O
published	O
today	O
(	O
31	O
Jul	O
2012	O
)	O
,	O
California	B-Province
State	O
Veterinarian	O
Annette	O
Whiteford	O
,	O
DVM	O
,	O
said	O
:	O
``	O
Each	O
year	O
,	O
we	O
find	O
ourselves	O
using	O
this	O
sad	O
occasion	O
to	O
remind	O
horse	O
owners	O
to	O
have	O
their	O
animals	O
vaccinated	O
.	O

It	O
offers	O
them	O
maximum	O
protection	O
against	O
the	O
disease	O
.	O

And	O
once	O
vaccinations	O
occur	O
,	O
horse	O
owners	O
should	O
be	O
checking	O
regularly	O
with	O
their	O
veterinarians	O
to	O
make	O
sure	O
they	O
stay	O
current	O
.	O
''	O

Clinical	O
signs	O
for	O
WNV	O
include	O
flu-like	O
signs	O
,	O
where	O
the	O
horse	O
seems	O
mildly	O
anorexic	O
and	O
depressed	O
;	O
fine	O
and	O
coarse	O
muscle	O
and	O
skin	O
fasciculations	O
(	O
twitching	O
)	O
;	O
hyperesthesia	O
(	O
hypersensitivity	O
to	O
touch	O
and	O
sound	O
)	O
;	O
changes	O
in	O
mentation	O
(	O
mentality	O
)	O
,	O
when	O
horses	O
look	O
like	O
they	O
are	O
daydreaming	O
or	O
``	O
just	O
not	O
with	O
it	O
;	O
''	O
occasional	O
somnolence	O
(	O
drowsiness	O
)	O
;	O
propulsive	O
walking	O
(	O
driving	O
or	O
pushing	O
forward	O
,	O
often	O
without	O
control	O
)	O
;	O
and	O
``	O
spinal	O
''	O
signs	O
,	O
including	O
asymmetrical	O
weakness	O
.	O

Some	O
horses	O
show	O
asymmetrical	O
or	O
symmetrical	O
ataxia	O
(	O
incoordination	O
on	O
one	O
or	O
both	O
sides	O
,	O
respectively	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
equine	O
mortality	O
rate	O
can	O
be	O
as	O
high	O
as	O
30-40	O
percent	O
.	O

The	O
USDA	O
Animal	O
and	O
Plant	O
Health	O
Inspection	O
Service	O
reported	O
83	O
cases	O
of	O
WNV	O
in	O

2011	O
,	O
with	O
15	O
of	O

cases	O

identified	O
in	O
California	B-Province
horses	O
.	O

Residents	O
of	O
Edo	B-Province
state	O
are	O
on	O
alert	O
following	O
a	O

of	O

fever	I-Disease
in	O
the	O
area	O
.	O

Nigeria	B-Country
News	O

that	O

of	O
the	O
killer	O
disease	O
in	O
the	O
state	O

in	O

,	O

,	O

.	O

by	O
the	O

's	O
Commissioner	O
for	O
Health	O
,	O
Dr	O
David	O
Osifo	O

on	O

,	O

's	O

.	O

said	O
:	O
``	O

should	O

and	O

rats	O
through	O
storage	O
in	O

.	O

that	O
can	O

into	O

's	O

.	O

and	O

.	O
''	O

.	O

the	O

of	O
garri	O
.	O
''	O

The	O

to	O

in	O

to	O
quickly	O

they	O
experience	O
any	O

which	O
relates	O
to	O
the	O
disease	O
.	O

20	O
cases	O
of	O
leishmaniasis	B-Disease
(	O
Kala-azar	O
)	O
were	O
reported	O
from	O
Jammu	B-Province
and	I-Province
Kashmir	I-Province
(	O
J	O
&	O
K	O
)	O
for	O

1st	O

this	O

[	O
2013	O
]	O

.	O

.	O

Parks	O
Canada	B-Country
officials	O
are	O
alerting	O
the	O
public	O
after	O
a	O
Saskatchewan	B-Province
prairie	O
dog	O
was	O
found	O
dead	O
of	O
plague	B-Disease
.	O

The	O
carcass	O
of	O
the	O
black-tailed	O
prairie	O
dog	O
was	O
found	O
on	O
the	O
edge	O
of	O
the	O
Larson	O
prairie	O
dog	O
colony	O
in	O
Grasslands	O
National	O
Park	O
in	O
the	O
southern	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
province	O
.	O

Tests	O
confirmed	O
the	O
rodent	O
had	O
been	O
infected	O
with	O
the	O
_Yersinia	O
pestis_	O
bacterium	O
,	O
the	O
same	O
type	O
of	O
organism	O
that	O
causes	O
bubonic	O
and	O
pneumonic	O
plague	B-Disease
in	O
humans	O
.	O

With	O
rodents	O
,	O
the	O
disease	O
is	O
called	O
sylvatic	O
plague	B-Disease
.	O

Park	O
officials	O
said	O
it	O
's	O
a	O
rare	O
but	O
naturally	O
occurring	O
disease	O
that	O
affects	O
squirrels	O
and	O
mice	O
throughout	O
the	O
southern	O
Prairies	O
.	O

Transmission	O
to	O
humans	O
occurs	O
through	O
infected	O
flea	O
bites	O
,	O
but	O
it	O
's	O
extremely	O
rare	O
for	O
people	O
to	O
contract	O
the	O
disease	O
,	O
Parks	O
Canada	B-Country
said	O
in	O
a	O
news	O
release	O
.	O

Grasslands	O
National	O
Park	O
will	O
remain	O
open	O
,	O
but	O
Parks	O
Canada	B-Country
is	O
recommending	O
that	O
visitors	O
not	O
walk	O
through	O
prairie	O
dog	O
colonies	O
.	O

Pets	O
are	O
now	O
banned	O
from	O
the	O
park	O
's	O
prairie	O
dog	O
colonies	O
.	O

Officials	O
are	O
also	O
advising	O
visitors	O
to	O
the	O
park	O
to	O
use	O
insect	O
repellent	O
on	O
their	O

and	O

.	O

Health	O
agencies	O
,	O
including	O
the	O
Public	O
Health	O
Agency	O
of	O
Canada	B-Country
and	O
the	O
Cypress	O
Health	O
Region	O
,	O

been	O

,	O
Parks	O
Canada	O
said	O
.	O

This	O
message	O
is	O
to	O
inform	O
American	O
citizens	O
residing	O
in	O
or	O
visiting	O
Cuba	B-Country
that	O
media	O
reports	O
have	O
indicated	O
that	O
cases	O
of	O
cholera	B-Disease
have	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O
the	O
city	O
of	O
Havana	B-City
,	O
possibly	O
linked	O
to	O
a	O
reported	O
outbreak	O
of	O
cholera	O
in	O
eastern	O
Cuba	O
.	O

The	O
Pan-American	O
Health	O
Organization	O
(	O
PAHO	O
)	O
issued	O
an	O
epidemiological	O
alert	O
noting	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
cholera	B-Disease
in	O
Cuba	B-Country
and	O
confirming	O
that	O
foreign	O
travelers	O
have	O
contracted	O
cholera	O
during	O
recent	O
trips	O
to	O
Cuba	O
.	O

Eating	O
or	O
drinking	O
fecally	O
contaminated	O
food	O
or	O
water	O
is	O
the	O
main	O
risk	O
factor	O
.	O

Unsterilized	O
water	O
,	O
food	O
from	O
street	O
vendors	O
,	O
raw	O
fish	O
dishes	O
(	O
e.g	O
.	O

ceviche	O
)	O

Unusual	O

were	O

in	O

in	O
North	B-Province

.	O

In	O
total	O
,	O

than	O
25	O
ha	O
of	O

were	O
affected	O
.	O

_Tomato	O
brown	O
rugose	O
fruit	O
virus_	O
(	O
ToBRFV	O
)	O
has	O
been	O
confirmed	O
in	O
7	O
greenhouses	O
;	O
one	O
further	O
greenhouse	O
is	O
suspected	O
to	O
be	O
infested	O
.	O

It	O
's	O
the	O
1st	O
report	O
of	O
ToBRFV	O
in	O
Germany	B-Country
.	O

The	O
infested	O
tomato	O
plants	O
were	O
used	O
for	O
tomato	O
fruit	O
production	O
.	O

Eradication	O
measures	O
are	O
in	O
progress	O
.	O

ToBRFV	O
infects	O
tomato	O
plants	O
and	O
leads	O
to	O
foliar	O
symptoms	O
,	O
including	O
chlorosis	O
mosaic	O
with	O
dark	O
green	O
bulges	O
and	O
narrowing	O
.	O

Fruit	O
symptoms	O
consisted	O
of	O
yellow	O
spots	O
,	O
often	O
concentrated	O
around	O
the	O
calyx	O
with	O
occasional	O
rugose	O
symptoms	O
rendering	O
the	O
fruits	O
non-marketable	O
.	O

The	O
virus	O
can	O
affect	O
up	O
to	O
100	O
%	O
of	O
a	O
crop	O
.	O

The	O
available	O
resistance	O
genes	O
in	O
conventional	O
tomato	O
varieties	O
against	O
other	O
tobamoviruses	O
are	O
ineffective	O
against	O
ToBRFV	O
.	O

So	O
far	O
,	O
too	O
little	O
is	O
known	O
about	O
the	O
virus	O
to	O
exclude	O
possible	O
damage	O
on	O
other	O
host	O
plants	O
.	O

The	O
virus	O
can	O
establish	O
in	O
greenhouses	O
[	O
and	O
]	O
outdoors	O
;	O
potential	O
host	O
plants	O
can	O
serve	O
as	O
reservoir	O
for	O
new	O
infections	O
.	O

Because	O
of	O
its	O
high	O
damaging	O
potential	O
for	O
tomato	O
production	O
,	O
ToBRFV	O
poses	O
a	O
significant	O
phytosanitary	O
risk	O
for	O
Germany	B-Country
and	O
other	O
EU	O
member	O
states	O
.	O

The	O
Institute	O
of	O
Public	O
Health	O
[	O
ISP	O
]	O
confirmed	O
the	O
results	O
of	O
tests	O

from	O

were	O

for	O
[	O
a	O
]	O
hantavirus	B-Virus
[	O
infection	O
]	O
.	O

Eastern	B-Virus
equine	I-Virus

in	O
2019	O
.	O

``	O
EEE	O
virus	O
is	O
a	O
rare	O
cause	O
of	O
brain	O
infections	O
.	O

Only	O
a	O

cases	O
are	O

the	O
United	B-Country
States	I-Country
each	O
year	O
,	O
''	O

Coast	O
states	O
.	O

.	O

[	O

.	O

not	O

of	O

in	O

.	O

other	O

.	O

of	O

An	O

of	O

is	O
the	O
best	O
way	O
to	O
prevent	O
mumps	B-Virus
.	O

who	O

not	O

should	O

a	O

.	O

Idaho	B-Province
Student	O
Health	O
Services	O
,	O
their	O

care	O

,	O

office	O
or	O
a	O
local	O
pharmacy	O
about	O
receiving	O
an	O
MMR	O
vaccine	O
.	O

Mumps	B-Virus
is	O
a	O
contagious	O
virus	O
that	O
spreads	O
from	O
person-to-person	O
via	O
droplets	O
of	O
saliva	O
or	O
mucus	O
from	O
the	O
mouth	O
,	O
nose	O
,	O
or	O
throat	O
of	O
an	O
infected	O
person	O
,	O
usually	O
when	O
the	O
person	O
coughs	O
,	O
sneezes	O
,	O
or	O
talks	O
.	O

An	O
infected	O
person	O
can	O
spread	O
the	O
virus	O
before	O
being	O
sick	O
.	O

The	O
virus	O
is	O
also	O
spread	O
when	O
someone	O
with	O
mumps	B-Virus
touches	O
items	O
or	O
surfaces	O
without	O
washing	O
their	O
hands	O
,	O
and	O
then	O
someone	O
else	O
touches	O
the	O
same	O
item	O
or	O
surface	O
and	O
rubs	O
their	O
mouth	O
or	O
nose	O
.	O

Symptoms	O
,	O
which	O
can	O
appear	O
up	O
to	O
25	O
days	O
after	O
being	O
exposed	O
,	O
may	O
include	O
fever	O
,	O
headache	O
,	O
muscle	O
aches	O
,	O
tiredness	O
,	O
loss	O
of	O
appetite	O
,	O
and	O
swollen	O
or	O
tender	O
salivary	O
glands	O
under	O
the	O
ears	O
on	O
one	O
or	O
both	O
sides	O
of	O
the	O
head	O
.	O

The	O
most	O
common	O
complication	O
of	O
mumps	B-Virus
infection	O
in	O
adults	O
is	O
testicular	O
inflammation	O
.	O

Rare	O
complications	O
include	O
meningitis	O
,	O
encephalitis	O
,	O
inflammation	O
of	O
the	O
ovaries	O
,	O
and	O
deafness	O
.	O

Anyone	O
experiencing	O
symptoms	O
compatible	O
with	O
mumps	B-Virus
should	O
contact	O
their	O
health	O
care	O
professional	O
.	O

Up	O
to	O
half	O
of	O
people	O
with	O
mumps	B-Virus
have	O
very	O
mild	O
or	O
no	O
symptoms	O
and	O
might	O
not	O
know	O
they	O
are	O
infected	O
.	O

Anyone	O
infected	O
with	O
the	O
mumps	B-Virus
virus	O
should	O
stay	O
home	O
for	O
5	O
days	O
after	O
symptoms	O
begin	O
,	O
while	O
minimizing	O
close	O
contact	O
with	O
other	O
people	O
.	O

Infected	O
people	O
should	O
avoid	O
sharing	O
drinks	O
or	O
eating	O
utensils	O
,	O
cover	O
all	O
coughs	O
and	O
sneezes	O
,	O
wash	O
their	O
hands	O
frequently	O
with	O
soap	O
and	O
water	O
,	O
and	O
regularly	O
clean	O
frequently	O
touched	O
surfaces	O
.	O

Five	O
citizens	O
in	O
Romania	B-Country
have	O
been	O
diagnosed	O
with	O

caused	O
by	O
the	O
West	B-Virus

.	O

.	O

A	O
typical	O
case	O
of	O
pertussis	B-Disease
starts	O
with	O
a	O
cough	O
and	O
runny	O
nose	O
for	O
one	O
to	O
2	O
weeks	O
,	O
followed	O
by	O
weeks	O
to	O
months	O
of	O
rapid	O
coughing	O
fits	O
that	O
sometimes	O
end	O
with	O
a	O
whooping	O
sound	O
Fever	O
,	O
if	O
present	O
,	O
is	O
usually	O
mild	O
.	O

Antibiotics	O
can	O
lessen	O
the	O
severity	O
of	O
symptoms	O
and	O
prevent	O
the	O
spread	O
of	O
disease	O
to	O
others	O
.	O

The	O
Centers	O
for	O
Disease	O
Control	O
and	O
Prevention	O
recommends	O
the	O
following	O
vaccination	O
schedule	O
:	O
-	O
young	O
children	O
need	O
5	O
doses	O
of	O
DTaP	O
by	O
kindergarten	O
:	O
at	O
2	O
months	O
,	O
4	O
months	O
,	O
6	O
months	O
,	O
15	O
to	O
18	O
months	O
,	O
and	O
4	O
to	O
6	O
years	O
.	O

-	O
all	O
students	O
entering	O
7th	O
grade	O
need	O
proof	O
of	O
a	O
whooping	O
cough	O
booster	O
immunization	O
(	O
Tdap	O
)	O
.	O

-	O
a	O
Tdap	O
booster	O
is	O
recommended	O
for	O
pregnant	O
women	O
during	O
their	O
third	O
trimester	O
of	O
each	O
pregnancy	O
,	O
even	O
if	O
they	O
got	O
a	O
booster	O
before	O
becoming	O
pregnant	O
.	O

-	O
one	O
dose	O
of	O
Tdap	O
is	O
recommended	O
for	O
adults	O
19	O
years	O
of	O
age	O
and	O
older	O
who	O
did	O
not	O
get	O
Tdap	O
as	O
an	O
adolescent	O
.	O

parents	O
can	O
obtain	O
the	O
DTaP	O
vaccine	O
series	O
and	O
the	O
Tdap	O
booster	O
shot	O
for	O
themselves	O
and	O
their	O
children	O
through	O
their	O
primary	O
care	O
physicians	O
.	O

Local	O
retail	O
pharmacies	O
offer	O
vaccinations	O
for	O
a	O
fee	O
,	O
and	O
anyone	O
who	O
is	O
not	O
covered	O
by	O
a	O
medical	O
insurance	O
plan	O
can	O
get	O
the	O
shot	O
from	O
a	O
County	O
Public	O
Health	O
Center	O
at	O
minimal	O
or	O
no	O
cost	O

Rat	O
fever	O
[	O
leptospirosis	B-Disease
]	O
cases	O
are	O
rising	O
.	O

Between	O
January	O
and	O
September	O
this	O
year	O
[	O
2020	O
]	O
,	O
173	O
rat	O
fever	O
cases	O
were	O
reported	O
.	O

A	O
total	O
of	O
85	O
of	O
them	O
were	O
from	O
Udupi	B-City
taluk	O
,	O
54	O
from	O
Kundapur	B-City
taluk	O
and	O
34	O
from	O
Karkala	B-City
taluk	O
.	O

Until	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
October	O
[	O
2020	O
]	O
,	O
203	O
such	O
cases	O
had	O
been	O
detected	O
.	O

In	O
January	O
[	O
2020	O
]	O
559	O
people	O
were	O
tested	O
,	O
and	O
24	O
showed	O
symptoms	O
of	O
this	O
fever	O
.	O

As	O
many	O
as	O
26	O
people	O
were	O
infected	O
in	O
February	O
,	O
23	O
more	O
in	O
March	O
,	O
5	O
in	O
May	O
,	O
11	O
in	O
June	O
,	O
32	O
in	O
July	O
and	O
25	O
in	O
August	O
.	O

The	O
highest	O
number	O
of	O
cases	O
was	O
reported	O
in	O
September	O
[	O
2020	O
]	O
,	O
with	O
a	O
total	O
of	O
34	O
cases	O
.	O

Among	O
them	O
,	O
17	O
were	O
from	O
Udupi	B-City
taluk	O
with	O
11	O
cases	O
from	O
Kundapur	B-City
and	O
6	O
from	O
Karkala	B-City
.	O

Fewer	O
cases	O
than	O
in	O
2019	O
,	O
when	O
344	O
cases	O
were	O
diagnosed	O
,	O
and	O
in	O
2018	O
[	O
330	O
]	O
.	O

This	O
fever	O
normally	O
spreads	O
through	O
the	O
urine	O
and	O
stools	O
of	O
the	O
rats	O
.	O

Usually	O
,	O
farmers	O
who	O
visit	O
the	O
fields	O
for	O
harvesting	O
paddy	O
crops	O
get	O
infected	O
.	O

During	O
the	O
4	O
months	O
of	O
lockdown	O
,	O
cases	O
were	O
minimal	O
.	O

The	O
district	O
reported	O
111	O
rat	O
fever	O
cases	O
from	O
January	O
[	O
2020	O
]	O
until	O
now	O
.	O

A	O
death	O
also	O
occurred	O
due	O
to	O
rat	O
fever	O
in	O
August	O
[	O
2020	O
]	O
.	O

As	O
people	O
avoided	O
going	O
out	O
because	O
of	O
the	O
coronavirus	O
pandemic	O
,	O
cases	O
seem	O
to	O
have	O
fallen	O
sharply	O
.	O

Moreover	O
,	O
when	O
the	O
ASHA	O
workers	O
visited	O
houses	O
to	O
create	O
awareness	O
about	O
coronavirus	O
,	O
they	O
also	O
talked	O
about	O
dengue	O
and	O
rat	O
fever	O
.	O

District	O
surveillance	O
officer	O
,	O
Dr	O
Jagadish	O
K	O
,	O
feels	O
that	O
this	O
would	O
have	O
resulted	O
in	O
a	O
steep	O
fall	O
in	O
the	O
cases	O
.	O

Precautions	O
Water	O
should	O
be	O
boiled	O
before	O
consumption	O
.	O

People	O
should	O
not	O
take	O
baths	O
in	O
standing	O
water	O
as	O
excreta	O
and	O
urine	O
of	O
animals	O
might	O
have	O
contaminated	O
that	O
water	O
.	O

Care	O
should	O
be	O
taken	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
food	O
items	O
,	O
fruits	O
,	O
vegetables	O
,	O
etc	O
are	O
not	O
accessible	O
to	O
rats	O
.	O

All	O
holes	O
,	O
cracks	O
,	O
etc	O
in	O
houses	O
,	O
godowns	O
,	O
drains	O
,	O
fields	O
,	O
etc	O
should	O
be	O
sealed	O
to	O
destroy	O
the	O
rats	O
,	O
and	O
carcasses	O
of	O
rats	O
should	O
be	O
properly	O
disposed	O
of	O
.	O

It	O
is	O
better	O
if	O
rubber	O
boots	O
are	O
worn	O
when	O
visiting	O
farms	O
,	O
cattle	O
sheds	O
,	O
agricultural	O
fields	O
,	O
etc	O
.	O

If	O
someone	O
works	O
in	O
slush	O
or	O
standing	O
water	O
,	O
they	O
should	O
take	O
a	O
bath	O
in	O
hot	O
water	O
afterwards	O
.	O

Dr	O
Sudhir	O
Chandra	O
Sooda	O
,	O
Udupi	B-City
district	O
health	O
officer	O
,	O
says	O
that	O
fever	O
occurs	O
when	O
viruses	O
from	O
the	O
discharges	O
of	O
rats	O
enter	O
the	O
human	O
body	O
.	O

Rat	O
fever	O
should	O
be	O
treated	O
at	O
its	O
initial	O
stage	O
.	O

Enough	O
stock	O
of	O
medicines	O
for	O
rat	O
fever	O
is	O
available	O
in	O
all	O
the	O
primary	O
health	O
centres	O
,	O
he	O
says	O
.	O

Udupi	B-City
district	O
has	O
not	O
witnessed	O
any	O
death	O
due	O
to	O
this	O
disease	O
,	O
he	O
said	O
.	O

Wyoming	B-Province
state	O
veterinarian	O
,	O
Dr	O
Jim	O

.	O

's	O

herds	O
out	O
of	O
infected	O
provinces	O
,	O
while	O
prices	O
in	O
the	O
south	O
have	O
increased	O
.	O
''	O

above	O
information	O
comes	O
from	O
a	O

``	O

Disease	O

``	O

Effective	O
anthrax	B-Disease
vaccines	O
are	O
readily	O
available	O
,	O
but	O
it	O
takes	O
about	O
a	O
week	O
for	O
immunity	O
to	O
be	O
established	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
must	O
be	O
administered	O
annually	O
for	O
continued	O
protection	O
.	O

Producers	O
should	O
monitor	O
their	O
herds	O
for	O
unexplained	O
deaths	O
and	O
work	O
with	O
their	O
veterinarian	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
appropriate	O
samples	O
are	O
collected	O
and	O
submitted	O
to	O
a	O
diagnostic	O
lab	O
to	O
give	O
the	O
best	O
chance	O
of	O
obtaining	O
a	O
diagnosis	O
.	O

Anthrax	B-Disease
has	O
been	O
most	O
frequently	O
reported	O
in	O
northeast	O
,	O
southeast	O
,	O
and	O
south-central	O
North	B-Province
Dakota	I-Province
,	O
but	O
it	O
has	O
been	O
found	O
in	O
almost	O
every	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
state	O
.	O

A	O
few	O
anthrax	B-Disease
cases	O
are	O
reported	O
in	O
North	B-Province
Dakota	I-Province
almost	O
every	O
year	O
.	O

In	O
2005	O
,	O
however	O
,	O
more	O
than	O
500	O
confirmed	O
deaths	O
from	O
anthrax	B-Disease
were	O
reported	O
with	O

estimated	O
at	O
more	O
than	O
1000	O
head	O
.	O

The	O

,	O

,	O

,	O

,	O

.	O

of	O

was	O

in	O
North	B-Province
Dakota	I-Province
in	O
2019	O
.	O

at	O
Anthrax	O
is	O
caused	O
by	O
the	O
bacterium	O
_Bacillus	O
anthracis_	O
.	O

The	O
bacterial	O
spores	O
can	O
lie	O
dormant	O
in	O
the	O
ground	O
for	O
decades	O
and	O
become	O
active	O
under	O
ideal	O
conditions	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
heavy	O
rainfall	O
,	O

and	O
drought	O
.	O

Animals	O
are	O
exposed	O
to	O
the	O
disease	O
when	O
they	O
graze	O
or	O
consume	O
forage	O
or	O
water	O
contaminated	O
with	O
the	O
spores	O
.	O

Maherisoa	O

endemic	O
in	O
Madagascar	B-Country
where	O
outbreaks	O
have	O
resurfaced	O
often	O
since	O
1980	O
and	O
are	O
blamed	O
mainly	O
on	O
rats	O
and	O
flea	O
infestation	O
due	O
to	O
unbridled	O
deforestation	O
.	O

Pneumonic	B-Disease
plague	I-Disease
can	O
be	O
spread	O
from	O
person	O
to	O
person	O
through	O
coughing	O
.	O

3	O

Madagascar	B-Country

.	O

Ebola	B-Virus
is	O
a	O
viral	O
haemorrhagic	O
fever	O
and	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
most	O
dangerous	O

to	O

.	O

There	O
is	O
no	O
known	O
treatment	O
or	O
vaccine	O
for	O
Ebola	B-Virus
,	O
which	O
is	O
transmitted	O
through	O
close	O
personal	O
contact	O
.	O

It	O
kills	O
up	O
to	O
90	O
percent	O
of	O
victims	O
.	O

Its	O
initial	O
symptoms	O
include	O
persistent	O
fever	O
,	O
intense	O
weakness	O
,	O
muscle	O

,	O

,	O

are	O
usually	O

by	O

,	O

,	O
rashes	O
on	O
the	O
body	O

as	O
external	O

.	O

APA	O
.	O

Somalia	B-Country
has	O
not	O

a	O

1991	O

General	O
Mohamed	O
Siyad	O
Barre	O
.	O

A	O
mystery	O
disease	O
that	O
usually	O
strikes	O
horses	O
in	O
Nordic	O
countries	O
during	O
the	O
winter	O
months	O
has	O
emerged	O
in	O
Iceland	B-Country
for	O
the	O
1st	O
time	O
,	O
leading	O
to	O
the	O
death	O
of	O
13	O
horses	O
.	O

Equine	B-Disease
polyneuropathy	I-Disease
(	O
AEP	O
)	O
,	O
also	O
known	O
as	O
Scandinavian	B-Disease
knuckling	I-Disease
syndrome	I-Disease
,	O
1st	O
appeared	O
in	O
Scandinavia	O
in	O
1995	O
,	O
and	O
,	O
despite	O
extensive	O
research	O
,	O
its	O
cause	O
has	O
never	O
been	O
identified	O
.	O

The	O
illness	O
presents	O
as	O
muscle	O
weakness	O
in	O
the	O
back	O
of	O
the	O
body	O
,	O
which	O
can	O
cause	O
the	O
fetlock	O
joints	O
to	O
knuckle	O
forward	O
,	O
giving	O
it	O
its	O
common	O
name	O
.	O

Horses	O
with	O
the	O
disease	O
exhibit	O
full	O
consciousness	O
,	O
good	O
appetite	O
,	O
and	O
mostly	O
normal	O
behaviour	O
.	O

AEP	O
is	O
neither	O
contagious	O
nor	O
genetic	O
and	O
usually	O
occurs	O
in	O
populations	O
fed	O
forage	O
,	O
between	O
late	O
winter	O
and	O
early	O
May	O
.	O

While	O
horses	O
are	O
able	O
to	O
make	O
a	O
full	O
recovery	O
,	O
statistics	O
from	O
Norway	O
and	O
Sweden	O
show	O
that	O
up	O
to	O
30	O
%	O
of	O
animals	O
who	O
contract	O
the	O
disease	O
have	O
to	O
be	O
put	O
down	O
.	O

The	O
Icelandic	O
Food	O
and	O
Veterinary	O
Authority	O
(	O
MAST	O
)	O
confirmed	O
the	O
country	O
's	O
1st	O
outbreak	O
in	O
a	O
herd	O
of	O
horses	O
at	O
a	O
large	O
horse	O
farm	O
in	O
northwest	B-Province
Iceland	B-Country
at	O
the	O
beginning	O
of	O
June	O
[	O
2019	O
]	O
.	O

Further	O
tests	O
have	O
brought	O
the	O
total	O
of	O
affected	O
horses	O
to	O
44	O
,	O
12	O
of	O
which	O
had	O
to	O
be	O
euthanised	O
,	O
while	O
one	O
was	O
found	O
dead	O
.	O

In	O
a	O
statement	O
,	O
Sigridur	O
Bjornsdottir	O
,	O
veterinary	O
officer	O
for	O
health	O
and	O
welfare	O
of	O
the	O
horse	O
at	O
MAST	O
,	O
said	O
the	O
disease	O
was	O
linked	O
to	O
hay	O
the	O
horses	O
had	O
been	O
fed	O
.	O

All	O
affected	O
animals	O
had	O
been	O
fed	O
with	O
hay	O
from	O
the	O
same	O
field	O
,	O
although	O
not	O
all	O
horses	O
who	O
ate	O
the	O
hay	O
showed	O
symptoms	O
.	O

``	O
AEP	O
has	O
not	O
been	O
found	O
on	O
any	O
other	O
farms	O
in	O
the	O
country	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
can	O
be	O
assumed	O
that	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
discovering	O
more	O
cases	O
this	O
year	O
[	O
2019	O
]	O
is	O
low	O
,	O
as	O
most	O
young	O
horses	O
are	O
now	O
grazing	O
.	O

There	O
is	O
a	O
risk	O
,	O
however	O
,	O
that	O
the	O
disease	O
will	O
arise	O
elsewhere	O
in	O
the	O
future	O
,	O
as	O
the	O
conditions	O
that	O
cause	O
it	O
have	O
now	O
clearly	O
appeared	O
in	O
Iceland	B-Country
,	O
''	O
the	O
statement	O
added	O
.	O

``	O
As	O
the	O
disease	O
is	O
new	O
to	O
the	O
country	O
,	O
MAST	O
requests	O
notification	O
of	O
all	O
cases	O
where	O
AEP	O
is	O
suspected	O
or	O
confirmed	O
.	O
''	O

AEP	O
is	O
found	O
most	O
commonly	O
in	O
Norway	O
but	O
also	O
in	O
Sweden	O
and	O
Finland	O
,	O
where	O
it	O
is	O
typical	O
for	O
there	O
to	O
be	O
a	O
cluster	O
of	O
cases	O
at	O
one	O
site	O
.	O

World	O
Horse	O
Welfare	O
has	O
been	O
made	O
aware	O
of	O
several	O
cases	O
of	O
equine	B-Disease
atypical	I-Disease
myopathy	I-Disease
(	O
EAM	O
)	O
in	O
the	O
UK	O
,	O
and	O
is	O
urging	O
horse	O
owners	O
to	O
monitor	O
their	O
own	O
horses	O
.	O

Liphook	O
Equine	O
Hospital	O
in	O
Hampshire	B-City
[	O
England	B-Province
]	O
have	O
issued	O
an	O
alert	O
that	O
they	O
have	O
diagnosed	O
5	O
cases	O
in	O
the	O
past	O
few	O
days	O
.	O

2	O
of	O
the	O
5	O
diagnosed	O
horses	O
have	O
died	O
.	O

Liphook	O
are	O
also	O
aware	O
of	O
a	O
further	O
4	O
cases	O
attended	O
by	O
veterinarians	O
which	O
have	O
died	O
in	O
the	O
Hampshire/Sussex/Surrey	O
area	O
.	O

EAM	O
is	O
a	O
disease	O
of	O
unknown	O
cause	O
which	O
results	O
in	O
significant	O
muscle	O
damage	O
.	O

The	O
condition	O
,	O
which	O
seems	O
to	O
be	O
becoming	O
more	O
common	O
,	O
affects	O
horses	O
at	O
pasture	O
,	O
often	O
in	O
the	O
spring	O
and/or	O
autumn	O
,	O
and	O
has	O
a	O
high	O
death	O
rate	O
.	O

Similarities	O
of	O
the	O
disease	O
have	O
been	O
made	O
with	O
equine	O
grass	O
sickness	O
as	O
it	O
is	O
a	O
pasture	O
related	O
disease	O
that	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
associated	O
with	O
an	O
adverse	O
change	O
in	O
weather	O
conditions	O
(	O
such	O
as	O
,	O
sudden	O
frost	O
,	O
heavy	O
rain	O
)	O
.	O

Signs	O
to	O
look	O
out	O
for	O
include	O
:	O
-	O
Weakness	O
and	O
stiffness	O
in	O
horses	O
at	O
pasture	O
-	O
not	O
related	O
to	O
excessive/unusual	O
exercise	O
-	O
Dark	O
coloured	O
urine	O
-	O
Collapse	O
-	O
Muscle	O
tremors	O
.	O

Notably	O
,	O
for	O
a	O
day	O
or	O
2	O
prior	O
to	O
referral	O
to	O
Liphook	O
,	O
the	O
5	O
horses	O
also	O
displayed	O
clinical	O
signs	O
less	O
well-recognised	O
in	O
atypical	O
myopathy	O
cases	O
.	O

These	O
signs	O
included	O
:	O
-	O
Vigorous	O
head	O
shaking	O
and	O
nodding	O
-	O
Frenzied	O
vocalisation	O
-	O
Recurrent	O
choke-like	O
retching	O
neck	O
spasms	O
without	O
a	O
persistent	O
oesophageal	O
obstruction	O
-	O
Stiffness	O
and	O
lethargy	O
when	O
ridden	O
Intensive	O
treatment	O
of	O
any	O
case	O
is	O
required	O
as	O
soon	O
as	O
possible	O
to	O
maximise	O
its	O
chances	O
of	O
survival	O
.	O

If	O
you	O
suspect	O
your	O
horse	O
has	O
atypical	O
myopathy	O
contact	O
your	O
vet	O
immediately	O
and	O
remove	O
the	O
horse	O
from	O
the	O
pasture	O
.	O

Any	O
other	O
animals	O
that	O
are	O
grazing	O
with	O
the	O
horse	O
you	O
are	O
concerned	O
about	O
should	O
also	O
be	O
removed	O
from	O
the	O
affected	O
pastures	O
immediately	O
,	O
as	O
it	O
is	O
possible	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
toxin	O
in	O
the	O
grass	O
,	O
released	O
only	O
during	O
changing	O
weather	O
conditions	O
,	O
which	O
causes	O
the	O
disease	O
.	O

Further	O
information	O
on	O
the	O
disease	O
can	O
be	O
obtained	O
from	O

less	O

3	O
weeks	O
for	O

to	O
resurface	O
in	O
South	B-Country

.	O

Texas	B-Province
Animal	O
Health	O
Commission	O
(	O
TAHC	O
)	O
officials	O
confirmed	O
equine	B-Virus
infectious	I-Virus
anemia	I-Virus
(	O
EIA	O
)	O
in	O
one	O
quarter	O
horse	O
on	O
a	O
Dallas	B-City
County	I-City
premises	O
on	O
26	O
Jan	O
2021	O
.	O

This	O
is	O
the	O
1st	O
confirmed	O
case	O
of	O
EIA	O
in	O
Texas	B-Province
this	O
year	O
[	O
2021	O
]	O
.	O

The	O
horse	O
was	O
confirmed	O
positive	O
after	O
testing	O
was	O
performed	O
to	O
meet	O
regulatory	O
requirements	O
.	O

The	O
premises	O
has	O
been	O
quarantined	O
and	O
will	O
not	O
be	O
released	O
until	O
TAHC	O
's	O
requirements	O
are	O
met	O
.	O

TAHC	O
staff	O
are	O
working	O
closely	O
with	O
the	O
owner	O
and	O
local	O
veterinarian	O
to	O
monitor	O
potentially	O
exposed	O
horses	O
and	O
implement	O
biosecurity	O
measures	O
.	O

``	O
Last	O
year	O
[	O
2020	O
]	O
,	O
17	O
horses	O
tested	O
positive	O
for	O
equine	B-Virus
infectious	I-Virus
anemia	I-Virus
in	O
Texas	B-Province
,	O
''	O
said	O
Dr	O
Andy	O
Schwartz	O
,	O
state	O
veterinarian	O
.	O

``	O
These	O
cases	O
serve	O
a	O
reminder	O
that	O
EIA	O
is	O
present	O
in	O
our	O
state	O
,	O
biosecurity	O
and	O
sanitary	O
practices	O
are	O
invaluable	O
,	O
and	O
required	O
EIA	O
testing	O
for	O
equine	O
event	O
participation	O
and	O
congregation	O
continues	O
to	O
be	O
of	O
the	O
utmost	O
importance	O
.	O
''	O

EIA	O
is	O
an	O
incurable	O
,	O
infectious	O
viral	O
disease	O
spread	O
through	O
blood-to-blood	O
contact	O
,	O
not	O
through	O
close	O
proximity	O
or	O
direct	O
contact	O
.	O

The	O
virus	O
can	O
be	O
transmitted	O
from	O
an	O
infected	O
equine	O
to	O
an	O
uninfected	O
equine	O
by	O
biting	O
flies	O
,	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
unsterilized	O
or	O
contaminated	O
medical	O
instruments	O
,	O
or	O
through	O
a	O
blood	O
transfusion	O
.	O

The	O
commonest	O
clinical	O
sign	O
of	O
acute	O
EIA	O
is	O
fever	O
,	O
which	O
often	O
precedes	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
other	O
signs	O
.	O

In	O
chronic	O
cases	O
,	O
signs	O
such	O
as	O
weight	O
loss	O
,	O
weakness	O
,	O
anemia	O
,	O
and	O
swelling	O
of	O
the	O
lower	O
legs	O
,	O
chest	O
and	O
abdomen	O
may	O
occur	O
.	O

The	O
TAHC	O
would	O
like	O
to	O
remind	O
horse	O
owners	O
all	O
Texas	B-Province
equine	O
participating	O
in	O
Texas	O
events	O
must	O
have	O
a	O
negative	O
EIA	O
test	O
,	O
performed	O
by	O
a	O
private	O
practitioner	O
,	O
within	O
the	O
past	O
12	O
months	O
.	O

Horse	O
owners	O
should	O
keep	O
the	O
EIA	O
test	O
document	O
or	O
``	O
Coggins	O
papers	O
''	O
available	O
when	O
traveling	O
with	O
horses	O
.	O

Contact	O
your	O
private	O
veterinarian	O
for	O
testing	O
.	O

Any	O
additional	O
Texas	B-Province
EIA	O
cases	O
this	O
year	O
[	O
2021	O
]	O
will	O
be	O
posted	O
on	O

Disease	O

(	O

)	O

.	O

The	O

The	O
Minnesota	B-Province
Department	O
of	O
Health	O
[	O
MDH	O
]	O
reported	O
3	O
cases	O
of	O

have	O

to	O

Inver	B-City
Grove	I-City

.	O

The	O

of	O
a	O

outbreak	O
of	O

being	O

the	O

.	O

The	O
ill	O

were	O
age	O
18	O

60	O
.	O

All	O
3	O

by	O
_Salmonella	O
[	O

]	O
Infantis	O
,	O

.	O

MDH	O
State	O

Dr	O

said	O
the	O

underscores	O

of	O

hands	O

after	O
handling	O
chicks	O
,	O
ducklings	O
,	O
or	O
other	O
birds	O
.	O

People	O
typically	O

from	O
poultry	O
by	O
hand-to-mouth	O
contact	O
.	O

Usually	O
this	O
happens	O
when	O
people	O
handle	O
birds	O
or	O
objects	O
in	O
their	O
environment	O
and	O
then	O
accidentally	O
touch	O
their	O
mouths	O
or	O
forget	O
to	O
wash	O
their	O

before	O
eating	O
or	O
drinking	O
.	O

Salmonellosis	B-Disease
can	O
also	O
be	O
contracted	O
by	O
eating	O
contaminated	O
foods	O
that	O
have	O
not	O
been	O
properly	O
prepared	O
and	O
handled	O
.	O

Health	O
recommends	O
that	O
the	O
public	O
protect	O
itself	O
by	O
avoiding	O
mosquito	O
bites	O
through	O
various	O
means	O
,	O
including	O
the	O
usage	O
of	O
mosquito	O
repellent	O
creams	O
,	O
placing	O
screens	O
on	O
windows	O
,	O
and	O
reporting	O
standing	O
stagnant	O
water	O
to	O
local	O
authorities	O

given	O
that	O
stagnant	O
water	O
is	O
often	O
a	O
breeding	O
ground	O
for	O
the	O
insects	O
.	O

The	O
virus	O
reportedly	O
resides	O
in	O
birds	O
;	O
mosquitoes	O
who	O
bite	O
birds	O
carrying	O
the	O
virus	O
can	O
transmit	O
it	O
to	O
humans	O
.	O

In	O
around	O
one	O
per	O
cent	O
of	O
cases	O
,	O
the	O
virus	O
poses	O
a	O
serious	O
danger	O
.	O

There	O
is	O
no	O

for	O
the	O
virus	O
,	O
and	O

therefore	O
,	O
the	O

method	O
to	O
combat	O

is	O
by	O
avoiding	O
contracting	O
the	O
disease	O
,	O

by	O
preventing	O
mosquito	O
bites	O
.	O

[	O
Sin	O
Nombre	O
]	O
hantavirus	B-Virus
,	O
which	O
can	O
be	O
deadly	O
,	O
is	O
carried	O

by	O

mice	O
[	O
_Peromyscus	O
maniculatus_	O
]	O
.	O

The	O
infected	O

excrete	O
the	O
virus	O
in	O
their	O

,	O
droppings	O
and	O

.	O

are	O

.	O

A	O
South	O

species	O
of	O

in	O
the	O
country	O
if	O

rabid	O
.	O

Scientists	O
studying	O
bat	O
poo	O
found	O
in	O
3	O
out	O
of	O
15	O

from	O

north	O

Brazil	B-Country
,	O

traces	O
of	O

from	O

,	O

The	O
bat	O

studied	O
is	O
usually	O
a	O

and	O
only	O

.	O

and	O

noted	O
significant	O
and	O

of	O
human	O

.	O

that	O

is	O
likely	O
to	O
be	O

in	O

'	O

.	O

``	O
The	O
record	O
of	O
humans	O
as	O
prey	O
and	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
blood	O
from	O

,	O
''	O
the	O
study	O
authors	O
write	O
in	O
the	O
paper	O
.	O

Humans	O
are	O
increasingly	O
inhabiting	O
the	O
forests	O
,	O
bringing	O
domestic	O
animals	O
with	O
them	O
.	O

The	O
birds	O

While	O
cases	O
are	O
declining	O
,	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
cases	O
reported	O
per	O
week	O
remains	O
slightly	O
higher	O

to	O
the	O

in	O
previous	O
years	O
.	O

date	O
,	O

400	O
cryptosporidium	O
cases	O
have	O
been	O
recorded	O
.	O

Most	O
cases	O
have	O
been	O

from	O
Stockholm	B-Province
,	O
Ostergotland	B-Province
,	O
Vastra	B-Province
Gotaland	I-Province
,	O
Halland	B-Province
,	O
Jonkoping	B-City
and	O
Uppsala	B-City
.	O

The	O
Public	O
Health	O
Authority	O
analysed	O
samples	O
from	O
the	O
cases	O
to	O
determine	O
what	O
type	O
of	O
cryptosporidium	O
they	O
have	O
become	O
ill	O
from	O
.	O

the	O
202	O
samples	O

so	O
far	O
,	O
93	O
have	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O
belong	O
to	O
subtype	O
(	O
A	O
)	O

to	O
subtype	O

of	O
_Cryptosporidium	O
parvum_	O
.	O

In	O

to	O
this	O
subtype	O
,	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
different	O
subtypes	O
have	O
been	O

.	O

The	O

are	O
seen	O

that	O
there	O
are	O
different	O
sources	O
of	O
infection	O
for	O
the	O
cases	O

during	O
the	O
fall	O
[	O
2019	O
]	O
.	O

the	O
survey	O
studies	O
,	O
it	O
was	O
shown	O
that	O
cases	O
with	O
subtype	O
A	O
have	O
drunk	O
to	O
a	O
greater	O
extent	O

and	O

drinks	O
that	O
are	O
no	O
longer	O
on	O
the	O
market	O
when	O
the	O
shelf	O
life	O
is	O
short	O
.	O

The	O
majority	O
(	O
almost	O
80	O
%	O
)	O
of	O
cases	O
with	O
subtype	O
A	O
were	O
reported	O
to	O

during	O

of	O
October	O
[	O
2019	O
]	O
,	O
which	O
indicates	O
that	O
the	O
outbreak	O
has	O

.	O

The	O

of	O

with	O
subtype	O
B	O
continues	O
,	O
and	O

of	O
the	O
infection	O
.	O

of	O

who	O
have	O
become	O
ill	O

what	O

before	O

.	O

far	O
,	O

to	O
the	O

source	O
of	O
infection	O
as	O
for	O
subtype	O
A	O
(	O
Subtype	O
A=IIdA22G1c	O
,	O
subtype	O
B=IIdA24G1	O
)	O
.	O

Nine	O
children	O
have	O

since	O
the	O

of	O
February	O

in	O

Dakahlia	B-Province

and	O

.	O

.	O

A	O
disease	O

to	O
be	O
malaria	B-Disease
rage	O
in	O
the	O

of	O
Lake	O
Munkamba	O
,	O

.	O

.	O

latest	O
ISA	B-Virus
outbreak	O

in	O
Chile	B-Country
was	O
in	O

.	O

that	O

in	O

and	O

that	O

JE	B-Virus

in	O

.	O

``	O

peak	O
season	O
for	O
JE	B-Virus
.	O

Humidity	O
and	O
rise	O
in	O
temperature	O
act	O
as	O

for	O
the	O

of	O

that	O
are	O
disease-carrying	O
vectors	O
for	O
the	O
JE	B-Virus
virus	O
.	O

Rain	O

away	O

grounds	O
during	O
floods	O
.	O

But	O

,	O

.	O

.	O

of	O

``	O

with	O
the	O
density	O

.	O

An	O
epidemic	O
of	O
typhoid	B-Disease
fever	I-Disease
has	O
been	O
confirmed	O
in	O
the	O
health	O
zone	O
of	O
Popokabaka	B-City
by	O
the	O
National	O
Institute	O
of	O

Research	O
(	O

)	O
.	O

this	O

[	O

]	O

typhoid	B-Disease
fever	I-Disease
is	O

[	O

]	O

<	O
tropmed	O
@	O

>	O
The	O

.	O

.	O

is	O

.	O

.	O

will	O

.	O

is	O

to	O

for	O
hepatitis	B-Virus
A	I-Virus
after	O
26	O
cases	O
of	O
the	O
liver	O
infection	O

the	O
state	O
since	O

2017	O
.	O

That	O
4-month	O
total	O
is	O
more	O
than	O
Colorado	B-Province
typically	O
sees	O
in	O
a	O
year	O
.	O

Most	O
of	O
the	O
cases	O
were	O
in	O
Front	B-City
Range	I-City
counties	O
and	O
all	O
involved	O
adults	O
.	O

Hepatitis	B-Virus
A	I-Virus
is	O
a	O
virus	O
contracted	O
by	O
eating	O
food	O
or	O
drinks	O
contaminated	O
with	O
fecal	O
matter	O
from	O
an	O
infected	O
person	O
or	O
through	O
sexual	O
contact	O
with	O
an	O
infected	O
person	O
,	O
including	O
oral-anal	O
contact	O
.	O

Those	O
at	O
higher	O
risk	O
include	O
men	O
who	O
have	O
sex	O
with	O
men	O
,	O
people	O
who	O
use	O
drugs	O
through	O
injection	O
,	O
and	O
people	O
who	O
are	O
homeless	O
.	O

Among	O
the	O
26	O
cases	O
reported	O
so	O
far	O
in	O
2017	O
,	O
the	O
majority	O
involved	O
men	O
and	O
more	O
than	O
half	O
involved	O
men	O
who	O
had	O
sex	O
with	O
men	O
.	O

Vaccines	O
are	O
routinely	O
recommended	O
for	O
children	O
but	O
most	O
adults	O
are	O
not	O
vaccinated	O
against	O
hepatitis	B-Virus
A	I-Virus
.	O

People	O
at	O
higher	O
risk	O
are	O
urged	O
to	O
get	O
the	O
vaccine	O
,	O
``	O
which	O
is	O
extremely	O
safe	O
and	O
highly	O
effective	O
,	O
''	O
said	O
state	O
epidemiologist	O
Rachel	O
Herlihy	O
.	O

Several	O
cases	O
of	O
illness	O
from	O
eating	O
raw	O
oysters	O
and	O
lab	O
detection	O
of	O
bacteria	O
that	O
can	O
make	O
people	O
sick	O
has	O
led	O
state	O
health	O
officials	O
to	O
close	O
2	O
Hood	B-City
Canal	I-City
growing	O
areas	O
.	O

Lab	O
tests	O
in	O
Hood	B-City
Canal	I-City
Six	O
,	O
which	O
runs	O
from	O
Hoodsport	B-City
south	O
and	O
east	O
to	O
the	O
boat	O
launch	O
area	O
at	O
Twanoh	B-City
State	I-City
Park	I-City
,	O
showed	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
_Vibrio	O
parahaemolyticus_	O
,	O
which	O
can	O
cause	O
an	O
illness	O
known	O
as	O
vibriosis	B-Disease
.	O

While	O
no	O

have	O
been	O

to	O

from	O
this	O

this	O
summer	O
[	O
2010	O
]	O

least	O
4	O

who	O

Hood	B-City

from	O

a	O

.	O

by	O

of	O

cases	O

this	O

[	O
2010	O
]	O
,	O
scattered	O
around	O
the	O
state	O
's	O

areas	O
.	O

Typically	O
,	O
Washington	B-Province
sees	O
about	O
50	O
cases	O
of	O
vibriosis	B-Disease
a	O
year	O
.	O

_Vibrio	O
parahaemolyticus_	O
is	O
found	O
naturally	O
in	O
the	O
environment	O
.	O

The	O
warm	O
temperatures	O
and	O
daytime	O
low	O
tides	O
are	O
likely	O
contributing	O
to	O
these	O
recent	O
cases	O
.	O

These	O
2	O
areas	O
are	O
closed	O
for	O
all	O
recreational	O
harvesting	O
of	O
oysters	O
.	O

Some	O
commercial	O
growers	O
may	O
still	O
harvest	O
oysters	O
from	O
these	O
areas	O
,	O
but	O

can	O
only	O
be	O

when	O
they	O
are	O
shucked	O
and	O
intended	O
to	O
be	O
cooked	O
before	O
consumption	O
.	O

The	O
illness	O
is	O
usually	O
moderate	O
and	O
lasts	O
for	O
2	O
to	O
7	O
days	O
;	O
it	O
can	O
be	O
more	O
serious	O
,	O
and	O
may	O
be	O
life	O
threatening	O
to	O
people	O
with	O
weak	O
immune	O
systems	O
or	O
chronic	O
liver	O
disease	O
.	O

Thorough	O
cooking	O
will	O
kill	O
the	O
bacteria	O
and	O
leave	O
the	O
shellfish	O
safe	O
to	O
eat	O
.	O

Food	O
safety	O
specialists	O
recommend	O
oysters	O
be	O
cooked	O
to	O
an	O
internal	O
temperature	O
of	O
145	O
deg	O
F	O
to	O
kill	O
the	O
bacteria	O
.	O

,	O
Bangladesh	B-Country
are	O

25	O
human	O
anthrax	O
cases	O
in	O
Shahzadpur	B-City
upazila	O
in	O
recent	O
days	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
local	O
media	O
.	O

This	O
is	O
the	O
3rd	O
wave	O
of	O
anthrax	O
cases	O
in	O
the	O
upazila	O
since	O
May	O
[	O
2016	O
]	O
.	O

The	O
outbreak	O
is	O
linked	O
to	O
anthrax	O
tainted	O
meat	O
.	O

All	O
the	O
cases	O
are	O
considered	O
cutaneous	B-Disease
anthrax	I-Disease
,	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
report	O
.	O

Anthrax	O
is	O
a	O
serious	O
infectious	O
disease	O
caused	O
by	O
gram-positive	O
,	O
rod-shaped	O
bacteria	O
known	O
as	O
_Bacillus	O
anthracis_	O
.	O

Anthrax	O
can	O
be	O
found	O
naturally	O
in	O
soil	O
and	O
commonly	O
affects	O
domestic	O
and	O
wild	O
animals	O
around	O
the	O
world	O
.	O

Although	O
it	O
is	O
rare	O
,	O
people	O
can	O
get	O
sick	O
with	O
anthrax	O
if	O
they	O
come	O
in	O
contact	O
with	O
infected	O
animals	O
or	O
contaminated	O
animal	O
products	O
Cutaneous	B-Disease
anthrax	I-Disease
occurs	O
when	O
the	O
spore	O
(	O
or	O
possibly	O
the	O
bacterium	O
)	O
enters	O
a	O
cut	O
or	O
abrasion	O
on	O
the	O
skin	O
.	O

It	O
starts	O
out	O
as	O
a	O
raised	O
bump	O
that	O
looks	O
like	O
an	O
insect	O
bite	O
.	O

It	O
then	O
develops	O
into	O
a	O
blackened	O
lesion	O
called	O
an	O
eschar	O
that	O
may	O
form	O
a	O
scab	O
.	O

Lymph	O
glands	O
in	O
the	O
area	O
may	O
swell	O
plus	O
edema	O
may	O
be	O
present	O
.	O

This	O
form	O
of	O
anthrax	O
responds	O
well	O
to	O
antibiotics	O
.	O

If	O
untreated	O
,	O
deaths	O
can	O
occur	O
if	O
the	O
infection	O
goes	O
systemic	O
.	O

95	O

of	O
cases	O
of	O
anthrax	O
are	O
cutaneous	O
.	O

.	O

Avian	B-Disease
botulism	I-Disease
is	O
caused	O
by	O
the	O
bacteria	O
_Clostridium	O
botulinum_	O
,	O
a	O
naturally	O
occurring	O
organism	O
living	O
in	O
lakes	O
and	O
ponds	O
.	O

Outbreaks	O
occur	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
combination	O
of	O
low	O
water	O
levels	O
,	O
warm	O

and	O
lack	O
of	O
oxygen	O
in	O
the	O
water	O
.	O

Council	O
rangers	O
had	O
been	O
investigating	O
the	O
deaths	O
of	O
ducks	O
in	O
both	O
parks	O
since	O
early	O

.	O

up	O

from	O
Marriott	B-City

.	O

``	O

ago	O
to	O

.	O

to	O

[	O

]	O
,	O

of	O

.	O

Two	O

in	O

,	O

,	O
and	O
one	O
in	O

.	O

Officials	O
confirm	O
this	O
most	O
recent	O

has	O
been	O

in	O
the	O
Lindale	B-City
area	O
.	O

According	O
to	O
the	O
Centers	O
for	O
Disease	O
Control	O
and	O
Prevention	O
,	O
bacteria	O
that	O
cause	O
infant	B-Disease

can	O
be	O
found	O
in	O
dust	O
and	O

,	O
even	O
after	O
cleaning	O
.	O

Infants	O
are	O
more	O

to	O
complications	O
because	O
their	O
digestive	O
tracts	O
are	O
not	O
developed	O
enough	O
to	O
fight	O
off	O
the	O
bacteria	O
which	O
then	O
begins	O
producing	O
toxins	O
.	O

Warning	O

of	O
infant	B-Disease

include	O

,	O

,	O

and	O

.	O

Botulism	O
is	O
not	O
contagious	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
CDC	O
.	O

A	O
yellow	B-Virus
fever	I-Virus
outbreak	O
in	O
Angola	B-Country
and	O
Congo	O
has	O
been	O

,	O

.	O

``	O

(	O

)	O

this	O

.	O

,	O
''	O

.	O

But	O

still	O

in	O

,	O

recently	O
,	O

.	O

At	O
the	O

of	O
August	O
[	O
2016	O
]	O

said	O
the	O
trend	O
was	O
``	O

positive	O
''	O
but	O
it	O
was	O
too	O
early	O
to	O
say	O
the	O
outbreak	O
had	O
been	O
stopped	O
completely	O
,	O
with	O
1000	O
confirmed	O
cases	O
and	O
up	O
to	O
6000	O
suspected	O
cases	O
of	O
the	O
mosquito-borne	O
disease	O
.	O

The	O
outbreak	O
is	O
the	O
worst	O
in	O
decades	O
among	O
unprotected	O
African	O
populations	O
and	O
has	O
killed	O
more	O
than	O
400	O
people	O
.	O

The	O
vaccination	O
campaigns	O
have	O
depleted	O
the	O
global	O
stockpile	O
of	O
6	O
million	O
doses	O
twice	O
this	O
year	O
,	O
forcing	O

to	O
switch	O
to	O

one-5th	O
of	O
the	O
normal	O
dose	O
,	O

that	O
the	O
WHO	O
says	O
gives	O

from	O
the	O
disease	O
.	O

On	O
Mon	O

from	O

and	O

in	O
Geneva	O
to	O

of	O
yellow	B-Virus
fever	I-Virus
.	O

The	O
risk	O
of	O
such	O
outbreaks	O
has	O
risen	O
due	O
to	O

and	O
increasing	O

of	O
the	O
population	O

and	O
this	O

was	O

Nino	O

,	O

.	O

The	O

,	O

.	O

South	B-Country
Korea	I-Country
on	O

[	O

]	O

.	O

to	O

.	O

.	O
''	O

The	O

were	O

,	O

the	O

in	O

.	O

An	O
ACT	O

said	O
the	O
numbers	O
of	O
mosquito-borne	O
disease	O
cases	O
increased	O
during	O

,	O
with	O

AKTH	O

20130131.1524034	O
:	O
``	O

Africa	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
Nigeria	B-Country
,	O
where	O
Lassa	B-Disease
fever	I-Disease
is	O

the	O
disease	O
is	O
a	O

of	O

and	O

.	O

fever	I-Disease
infection	O

no	O

is	O

,	O
during	O
which	O

.	O

There	O
is	O
no	O

.	O

has	O
been	O
used	O
with	O
success	O
in	O
Lassa	B-Disease
fever	I-Disease
patients	O
.	O
''	O

The	O
virus	O
is	O
a	O
member	O
of	O
the	O
family	O
_Arenaviridae_	O
and	O
causes	O
acute	O

to	O

of	O
the	O

rodent	O
host	O
.	O

of	O

Visits	O
to	O
the	O
farm	O
are	O
allowed	O
only	O
to	O
professionals	O
due	O
to	O
their	O
specified	O
responsibilities	O
.	O

Other	O
visits	O
are	O
not	O
allowed	O
for	O
90	O
days	O
after	O
infection	O
.	O

Since	O
the	O
large	O
outbreak	O
of	O
Q	B-Disease
fever	I-Disease
,	O
all	O

and	O

in	O
the	O
Netherlands	B-Country
are	O

against	O
_Coxiella	O
burnetii_	O
.	O

This	O

[	O
2012	O
]	O

started	O
in	O
early	O
April	O
2012	O
.	O

All	O
animals	O
must	O

vaccinated	O
before	O
1	O
Aug	O
2012	O
.	O

In	O

.	O

.	O

Health	O

are	O
testing	O
samples	O
of	O
the	O
food	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
clinical	O
samples	O
from	O
the	O

who	O

have	O
been	O
infected	O
to	O

for	O

of	O
the	O

.	O

Testing	O
takes	O
about	O
a	O
week	O
,	O
Castrodale	O
said	O
.	O

Botulism	B-Disease
is	O
a	O
life-threatening	O
disease	O
and	O
a	O
public	O
health	O
emergency	O
.	O

The	O
bacteria	O
can	O
incubate	O
in	O
some	O
traditional	O
Alaska	B-Province
native	O
foods	O
including	O
fermented	O
``	O
stink	O
heads	O
,	O
''	O
which	O
some	O
in	O
the	O
Yukon-Kuskokwim	O
region	O
consider	O
a	O
delicacy	O
,	O
but	O
others	O
stay	O
away	O
from	O
.	O

The	O
traditional	O
way	O
of	O
aging	O
the	O
fish	O
in	O
grass	O
or	O
straw	O
has	O
given	O
way	O
to	O
glass	O
or	O
plastic	O
containers	O
that	O
can	O
increase	O
the	O
risk	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
a	O
2011	O
state	O
report	O
,	O
``	O
Botulism	B-Disease
in	O
Alaska	B-Province
.	O
''	O

If	O
officials	O
confirm	O
that	O
the	O
man	O
died	O
from	O
botulism	B-Disease
,	O
it	O
will	O
be	O
the	O
1st	O
Alaska	B-Province
death	O
from	O
the	O
bacteria	O
since	O
2007	O
,	O
Castrodale	O
said	O
.	O

Health	O
care	O
providers	O
are	O
urged	O
to	O
immediately	O
report	O
suspected	O
cases	O
to	O
ensure	O
quick	O
treatment	O
and	O
to	O
stop	O
others	O
from	O
eating	O
suspect	O
food	O
.	O

People	O
may	O
suffer	O
from	O
nausea	O
,	O
diarrhea	O
,	O
blurred	O
vision	O
,	O
skeletal	O
muscular	O
weakness	O
and	O
partial	O
paralysis	O
.	O

Two	O
horses	O
and	O
a	O
donkey	O
were	O
euthanised	O
in	O
Gorakhpur	B-City
[	O
Uttar	B-Province
Pradesh	I-Province
]	O
on	O
after	O
they	O
were	O
detected	O
with	O
the	O

glanders	B-Disease
disease	I-Disease
.	O

A	O
high	O
alert	O
has	O
been	O
sounded	O
in	O
the	O
district	O
and	O
movement	O
of	O
equines	O
--	O
horses	O
,	O
ponies	O
,	O
mules	O
,	O
and	O
donkeys	O
--	O
has	O
been	O
restricted	O
.	O

The	O
disease	O
can	O
spread	O
quickly	O
in	O

and	O
also	O
infect	O

.	O

This	O
is	O

in	O
Gorakhpur	B-City
.	O

hedgehog	O
's	O
feces	O
.	O

Farmers	O
in	O
Sarpang	B-City
[	O
Geylegphug	B-City
]	O
are	O

chilli	O
plants	O
to	O
a	O
new	O
disease	O
,	O

is	O

.	O

,	O

GS	O
Rai	O
,	O
Agriculture	O
Research	O
and	O
Development	O
Centre	O
(	O

)	O
,	O
said	O
the	O
yellowing	B-Disease
disease	I-Disease
is	O

.	O

``	O

The	O

.	O

.	O

.	O

[	O

The	O
Illinois	B-Province
Department	O
of	O
Public	O
Health	O
(	O

)	O

,	O
is	O

's	O

's	O

.	O

after	O

Rolf	O

.	O

Rolf	O
's	O

.	O

's	O

1	O
Nov	O
2010	O
.	O

Rolf	O

1	O
Nov	O
2010	O
.	O

Initial	O
laboratory	O
testing	O
shows	O
one	O
food	O
item	O
to	O
be	O
contaminated	O
with	O
high	O
levels	O
of	O
_Staphylococcus	O
aureus_	O
.	O

Food	O
can	O
become	O
contaminated	O
if	O
a	O
person	O
with	O
a	O
staph	O
infection	O
has	O
an	O
uncovered	O
lesion	O
or	O
sore	O
that	O
comes	O
in	O
contact	O
with	O
food	O
or	O
food	O
processing	O
equipment	O
.	O

_Staphylococcus	O
aureus_	O
bacteria	O
and	O
toxin	O
can	O
contaminate	O
foods	O
or	O
equipment	O
.	O

Staphylococcal	O
enterotoxins	O
are	O
fast	O
acting	O
,	O
sometimes	O
causing	O
illness	O
in	O
as	O
little	O
as	O
30	O
minutes	O
but	O
usually	O
in	O
4-6	O
hours	O
,	O
with	O
nausea	O
,	O
vomiting	O
,	O
stomach	O
cramps	O
,	O
and	O
little	O
if	O
any	O
fever	O
.	O

The	O
patients	O
usually	O
recover	O
within	O
a	O
day	O
.	O

Guernsey	B-Country
horse	O
owners	O
have	O
been	O
told	O
to	O
take	O
necessary	O
precautions	O
after	O
suspected	O
cases	O
of	O

on	O
the	O

.	O

of	O

.	O

.	O

fever	I-Disease
is	O

[	O

]	O

of	O
these	O

are	O

.	O

In	O

Niger	B-Country
,	O

outbreak	O

.	O

[	O

during	O

.	O

[	O

are	O

.	O

An	O

of	O
[	O

]	O
norovirus	B-Virus
at	O

24	O
.	O

.	O

unwell	O

.	O

The	O
ward	O

on	O

[	O
13	O
Jul	O
2021	O
]	O
.	O

Only	O

who	O

.	O

the	O

in	O
and	O

of	O

.	O

Staff	O
were	O

and	O

when	O
they	O

patients	O
.	O

The	O
source	O
of	O
the	O

was	O
not	O

,	O
while	O
the	O

to	O

did	O
not	O

.	O

Billinghurst	O
said	O
norovirus	B-Virus
was	O
highly	O
infectious	O
and	O
could	O
spread	O
in	O
many	O
ways	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
consuming	O
contaminated	O
food	O
or	O
drinks	O
,	O
or	O
contact	O
with	O
an	O
infected	O
person	O
.	O

It	O
could	O
survive	O
on	O
contaminated	O
surfaces	O
even	O
after	O
cleaning	O
with	O
some	O
disinfectants	O
.	O

Common	O
symptoms	O
included	O
vomiting	O
,	O
diarrhea	O
,	O
and	O
stomach	O
pains	O
.	O

Most	O
people	O
recovered	O
quickly	O
,	O
but	O
it	O
could	O
be	O
serious	O
for	O
some	O
people	O
,	O
particularly	O
if	O
they	O
became	O
dehydrated	O
.	O

Children	O
,	O
the	O
elderly	O
,	O
and	O
people	O
with	O
weak	O
immune	O
systems	O
were	O
more	O
likely	O
to	O
be	O
seriously	O
ill	O
.	O

An	O
outbreak	O
of	O
norovirus	B-Virus
at	O
Dr	O
Gray	O
's	O
Hospital	O
in	O
Elgin	B-City
has	O
caused	O
the	O
hospital	O
to	O
close	O
to	O
new	O
admissions	O
.	O

Only	O
the	O
emergency	O
department	O
will	O
be	O
open	O
for	O
those	O
with	O
life-threatening	O
conditions	O
.	O

The	O
outbreak	O
,	O
which	O
has	O
affected	O
23	O
patients	O
and	O
staff	O
across	O
several	O
wards	O
,	O
follows	O
a	O
period	O
of	O
high	O
levels	O
of	O
norovirus	B-Virus
being	O
experienced	O
in	O
the	O
community	O
.	O

This	O
,	O
coupled	O
with	O
the	O
pressures	O
from	O
the	O
rise	O
in	O
COVID	O
cases	O
,	O
has	O
left	O
the	O
hospital	O
under	O
extreme	O
pressure	O
with	O
a	O

of	O
beds	O
.	O

Hospital	O
manager	O
Alasdair	O
Pattinson	O
said	O
that	O
patients	O
in	O
immediate	O

Leptospirosis	B-Disease
is	O
a	O
bacterial	O
disease	O
that	O
can	O
damage	O
the	O
liver	O
,	O
lungs	O
and	O
kidney	O
,	O
and	O
may	O
be	O
fatal	O
in	O
some	O
cases	O
.	O

It	O
spreads	O
through	O
soil	O
and	O
water	O
contaminated	O
with	O
the	O
urine	O
of	O
infected	O
animals	O
,	O
particularly	O
rodents	O
,	O
and	O
enters	O
the	O
human	O
body	O
through	O
cuts	O
.	O

Nearly	O
a	O
dozen	O
people	O
,	O
including	O
several	O
marines	O
,	O
at	O
Joint	O
Base	O
Myer-Henderson	O
Hall	O
fell	O
ill	O
[	O
on	O

27	O

2018	O
]	O
after	O
they	O
opened	O

substance	O
.	O

.	O

few	O
days	O
before	O
illness	O
onset	O
.	O

His	O
home	O
contacts	O
and	O
colleagues	O
were	O
asymptomatic	O
.	O

Human	O
_Streptococcus	O
suis_	O
infection	O
is	O
a	O
zoonotic	O
infection	O
associated	O
with	O
pigs	O
.	O

The	O
infection	O
can	O
be	O
fatal	O
,	O
particularly	O
if	O
the	O
specific	O
strain	O
produces	O
certain	O
toxins	O
.	O

_S	O
.	O

suis_	O
infection	O
can	O
manifest	O
itself	O
in	O
meningitis	O
,	O
toxic	O
shock	O
,	O
septicemia	O
and	O
endocarditis	O
.	O

Eating	O
undercooked	O
infected	O
pork	O
and	O
blood	O
paste	O
are	O
common	O
ways	O
people	O
contract	O
the	O
disease	O
.	O

Proper	O
cooking	O
of	O
pork	O
meat	O
or	O
porcine	O
organs	O
eliminates	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
infection	O
with	O
_Streptococcus	O
suis_	O
.	O

The	O
infection	O
in	O
humans	O
is	O
not	O
only	O
seen	O
in	O
those	O
who	O
consume	O
raw	O
pork	O
,	O
but	O
also	O
in	O
those	O
who	O
slaughter	O
and	O
prepare	O
the	O
meals	O
.	O

_Streptococcus	O
suis_	O
infection	O
can	O
be	O
treated	O
with	O
appropriate	O
antibiotics	O
.	O

To	O
prevent	O
the	O
disease	O
,	O
members	O
of	O
the	O
public	O
are	O
advised	O
to	O
always	O
practice	O
personal	O
and	O
environmental	O
hygiene	O
.	O

They	O
should	O
avoid	O
contact	O
with	O
pigs	O
that	O
are	O
sick	O
or	O
dead	O
from	O
diseases	O
and	O
their	O
excreta	O
or	O
body	O
fluid	O
.	O

If	O
contact	O
with	O
pigs	O
or	O
raw	O
pork	O
is	O
necessary	O
,	O
one	O
should	O
:	O
use	O
protective	O
gloves	O
;	O
wash	O
hands	O
after	O
handling	O
pigs	O
or	O
raw	O
pork	O
;	O
and	O
clean	O
and	O
cover	O
all	O
wounds	O
properly	O
.	O

London	B-City
,	O
UK	O
--	O
November	O
1	O
,	O
2007	O
--	O
A	O
mysterious	O
skin	B-Disease
disorder	I-Disease
affecting	O
farmers	O
at	O
lambing	O
time	O
has	O
been	O
discovered	O
by	O
a	O
Hampshire	O
farmer	O
and	O
a	O
team	O
of	O
doctors	O
from	O
Southampton	O
,	O
the	O
British	O
Journal	O
of	O
Dermatology	O
will	O
reveal	O
.	O

Following	O
several	O
turbulent	O
months	O
for	O
UK	O
farmers	O
,	O
with	O
outbreaks	O
of	O
foot	O
and	O
mouth	O
and	O
blue	O

,	O

have	O
now	O
discovered	O
a	O
disorder	O
which	O
affects	O
the	O
farmers	O

.	O

The	O
strange	O
disorder	O
specifically	O
targets	O
the	O
ears	O
,	O
which	O
initially	O
become	O
hot	O
,	O
itchy	O
and	O
sore	O
and	O
soon	O
suffer	O
blistering	O
and	O
crusting	O
which	O
can	O

and	O
unsightly	O
.	O

No	O

parts	O
of	O
the	O
body	O
are	O
affected	O
.	O

The	O
symptoms	O
are	O
also	O
confined	O
to	O
lambing	O
season	O
(	O
which	O
usually	O
lasts	O
from	O
one	O
to	O
3	O
months	O
)	O
and	O
disappear	O
promptly	O
when	O
lambing	O
is	O
over	O
.	O

In	O
some	O

appears	O
every	O
year	O
during	O
lambing	O

one	O
case	O
for	O
the	O
previous	O
30	O
years	O
,	O
and	O
in	O
all	O
patients	O
both	O
ears	O
are	O
affected	O
.	O

It	O
also	O
occurs	O
in	O
farmers	O
who	O
are	O
calving	O
,	O
but	O
less	O
frequently	O
.	O

.	O

Hepatitis	B-Virus
E	I-Virus
is	O
found	O
worldwide	O
,	O
and	O
different	O
genotypes	O
of	O
the	O
hepatitis	B-Disease
E	I-Disease
virus	I-Disease
determine	O
differences	O
in	O
epidemiology	O
,	O
including	O
genotypes	O
that	O
are	O
zoonotic	O
.	O

For	O
example	O
,	O
genotype	O
1	O
is	O
usually	O
seen	O
in	O
developing	O
countries	O
and	O
causes	O
community-level	O
outbreaks	O
,	O
whereas	O
zoonotic	O
genotype	O
3	O
is	O
usually	O
seen	O
in	O
developed	O
countries	O
and	O
does	O
not	O
cause	O
outbreaks	O
.	O

Acute	O
epidemic	O
hepatitis	B-Virus
E	I-Virus
is	O
attributable	O
to	O
infection	O
with	O
hepatitis	B-Disease
E	I-Disease
virus	I-Disease
genotypes	O
1	O
and	O
2	O
.	O

Many	O
of	O
the	O
deaths	O
are	O
in	O
pregnant	O
women	O
,	O
characteristic	O
of	O
genotype	O
1	O
.	O

Allen	B-City
County	I-City
health	O
officials	O
are	O
tracking	O
a	O
syphilis	B-Disease
outbreak	O
that	O
has	O
seen	O
6	O
pregnant	O
women	O
and	O
2	O
infants	O
infected	O
in	O
the	O
last	O
2	O
years	O
.	O

The	O
sexually	O
transmitted	O
infection	O
,	O
which	O
was	O
once	O
the	O
target	O
of	O
public	O
health	O
campaigns	O
to	O
eliminate	O
the	O
disease	O
from	O
the	O
U.S.	O
,	O
can	O
cause	O
brain	O
damage	O
,	O
blindness	O
,	O
deafness	O
and	O
even	O
death	O
when	O
left	O
untreated	O
.	O

The	O
outbreak	O
began	O
last	O
year	O
[	O
2021	O
]	O
as	O
Allen	B-City
County	I-City
health	O
officials	O
identified	O
28	O
syphilis	B-Disease
cases	O
,	O
including	O
4	O
pregnant	O
women	O
and	O
2	O
infants	O
--	O
a	O
40	O
%	O
increase	O
from	O
2020	O
.	O

Health	O
officials	O
have	O
identified	O
another	O
18	O
syphilis	B-Disease
cases	O
,	O
2	O
of	O
whom	O
were	O
pregnant	O
,	O
through	O
June	O
of	O
this	O
year	O
[	O
2022	O
]	O
.	O

``	O
When	O
we	O
started	O
seeing	O
these	O
cases	O
,	O
it	O
alerted	O
us	O
that	O
there	O
was	O

to	O
be	O
a	O

,	O
''	O
said	O
Dr.	O
Wilfred	O
Ellis	O
,	O
an	O
infectious	O
diseases	O
physician	O
and	O

of	O
the	O
Allen	B-City
County	I-City

of	O
Health	O
.	O

Contact	O

have	O
been	O
working	O
to	O
identify	O
other	O
partners	O
who	O
may	O
have	O
been	O
exposed	O
.	O

At	O
times	O
,	O

said	O
,	O
those	O
partners	O
have	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O
other	O
states	O
or	O
counties	O
due	O
in	O
part	O
to	O
the	O
prevalence	O
of	O
online	O
dating	O
apps	O
,	O
a	O
new	O
risk	O
factor	O
.	O

Many	O
of	O
the	O
cases	O
identified	O
last	O
year	O
[	O
2021	O
]	O
had	O
developed	O
late-stage	O
neurosyphilis	O
,	O
while	O
several	O
others	O
had	O
developed	O
ocular	O
or	O
otosyphilis	O
--	O
syphilis	B-Disease
of	O
the	O
eyes	O
and	O
ears	O
,	O
Ellis	O
said	O
.	O

While	O
the	O
infection	O
is	O
treatable	O
with	O
antibiotics	O
,	O
the	O
symptoms	O
of	O
primary	O
and	O
secondary	O
stage	O
syphilis	B-Disease
are	O
often	O
painless	O
and	O
go	O
unnoticed	O
:	O
a	O
sore	O
develops	O
near	O
the	O
source	O
of	O
the	O
infection	O
for	O
3	O
to	O
6	O
weeks	O
,	O
followed	O
by	O
a	O
faint	O
rash	O
or	O
sores	O
in	O
the	O
mouth	O
,	O
private	O
areas	O
or	O
on	O
the	O
palms	O
and	O
soles	O
of	O
a	O
person	O
's	O
feet	O
.	O

But	O
left	O
untreated	O
,	O
the	O
disease	O
may	O
spread	O
to	O
the	O
brain	O
,	O
nervous	O
system	O
,	O
eyes	O
and	O
ears	O
.	O

In	O
rare	O
cases	O
,	O
syphilis	B-Disease
may	O
progress	O
to	O
the	O
tertiary	O
or	O
late	O
stage	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
disease	O
damages	O
internal	O
organs	O
,	O
possibly	O
resulting	O
in	O
death	O
.	O

And	O
for	O
pregnant	O
women	O
,	O
untreated	O
syphilis	B-Disease
introduces	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
passing	O
the	O
infection	O
on	O
to	O
the	O
child	O
,	O
who	O
may	O
in	O
turn	O
suffer	O
from	O
cataracts	O
,	O
seizures	O
,	O
hearing	O
loss	O
or	O
death	O
.	O

In	O
an	O
infant	O
,	O
a	O
copper-colored	O
rash	O
on	O
its	O
palm	O
is	O
a	O
sign	O
of	O
congenital	O
syphilis	B-Disease
.	O

The	O
infection	O
can	O
cause	O
bone	O
damage	O
,	O
anemia	O
,	O
jaundice	O
,	O
nerve	O

,	O

,	O
skin	O

and	O
an	O
enlarged	O
liver	O
or	O
spleen	O
.	O

The	O
CDC	O
estimates	O
40	O
%	O
of	O
children	O
born	O
to	O
women	O
with	O
untreated	O
syphilis	B-Disease
can	O
be	O
stillborn	O
or	O
die	O
from	O
the	O
infection	O
as	O
a	O
newborn	O
.	O

A	O
similar	O
trend	O
is	O
occurring	O
elsewhere	O
in	O
Ohio	B-Province
and	O
the	O
U.S.	O
,	O
undoing	O
decades	O
of	O
disease	O
elimination	O
efforts	O
.	O

The	O
Ohio	B-Province
Department	O
of	O
Health	O
sent	O
a	O

to	O

care	O
providers	O
in	O
April	O
[	O
2022	O
]	O

in	O

3rd	O

after	O

.	O

Ohio	B-Province
law	O
requires	O
pregnant	O
women	O
to	O
undergo	O
syphilis	B-Disease
screening	O
at	O
their	O
1st	O

visit	O
.	O

At	O
least	O
6	O
workers	O
of	O
the	O
Juan	O
Ramon	O
Jimenez	O
de	O
Huelva	B-City
hospital	O
are	O
affected	O
by	O
an	O

of	O
scabies	B-Disease
,	O

to	O

of	O
the	O
SATSE	O

.	O

.	O

SATSE	O
explained	O
that	O
scabies	B-Disease
is	O
a	O
mild	O

disease	O
that	O
requires	O
a	O
non-aggressive	O
treatment	O
,	O
because	O

of	O
a	O

and	O
enough	O
protection	O

symptoms	O
improve	O
or	O
even	O
disappear	O
.	O

Scabies	B-Disease
is	O
spread	O
by	O
indirect	O
contact	O
through	O
sheets	O
or	O
clothing	O
,	O
or	O
by	O
direct	O
contact	O
,	O
although	O
in	O
the	O
case	O
of	O
health	O
professionals	O
the	O

is	O
less	O

because	O
they	O
work	O
with	O

.	O

The	O
same	O
sources	O
have	O
indicated	O
that	O
it	O
is	O
sometimes	O
difficult	O
to	O
detect	O
because	O
this	O
skin	O

is	O
often	O

as	O

or	O

,	O

days	O
.	O

SATSE	O
considers	O
it	O

whether	O

``	O
has	O

''	O

.	O

)	O

'	I-Disease

to	O

.	O

The	O
facility	O
has	O
already	O
put	O
protective	O
measures	O
in	O
place	O
like	O
flushing	O
the	O
water	O
system	O
,	O

or	O
replacing	O
water	O
fixtures	O
,	O
and	O

filters	O
on	O
sinks	O
.	O

Legionnaires	B-Disease
'	I-Disease
disease	I-Disease
is	O
a	O
respiratory	O
infection	O
caused	O
by	O
_Legionella_	O
bacteria	O
.	O

These	O
bacteria	O
can	O
also	O
cause	O
a	O
milder	O
illness	O
called	O
Pontiac	O
fever	O
.	O

The	O
signs	O
and	O
symptoms	O
of	O
Legionnaires	B-Disease
'	I-Disease
disease	I-Disease
include	O
fever	O
,	O
cough	O
,	O
shortness	O
of	O
breath	O
,	O
muscle	O
aches	O
,	O
pneumonia	O
,	O
and	O
sometimes	O
diarrhea	O
and	O
abdominal	O
pain	O
.	O

Pontiac	O
fever	O
has	O
similar	O
symptoms	O
but	O
does	O
not	O
progress	O
to	O
pneumonia	O
.	O

Antibiotics	O
are	O
highly	O
effective	O
against	O
_Legionella_	O
bacteria	O
.	O

_Salmonella_	O
in	O
chicken	O
has	O
been	O
linked	O
to	O
over	O
70	O
cases	O
in	O
the	O
Czech	B-Country
Republic	I-Country
.	O

Health	O
authorities	O
in	O
the	O
city	O
of	O
Zlin	B-City
reported	O
the	O
outbreak	O
in	O
the	O
middle	O
of	O
March	O
2019	O
at	O
Tomase	O
Bati	O
Regional	O
Hospital	O
.	O

A	O
total	O
of	O
68	O
people	O
,	O
of	O
whom	O
38	O
were	O
patients	O
and	O
30	O
staff	O
,	O
were	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
connected	O
with	O
the	O
salmonellosis	B-Disease
outbreak	O
.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
4	O
people	O
--	O
1	O
staff	O
member	O
and	O
3	O
other	O
patients	O
--	O
were	O
hospitalized	O
in	O
the	O
town	O
of	O
Uherske	O
Hradiste	O
.	O

A	O
common	O
vehicle	O
of	O
infection	O
was	O
a	O
chicken	O
and	O
rice	O
dish	O
served	O
for	O
lunch	O
on	O
14	O
Mar	O
2019	O
.	O

An	O
epidemiological	O
survey	O
found	O
that	O
all	O
patients	O
consumed	O
this	O
lunch	O
.	O

The	O
alarm	O
was	O
raised	O
on	O
15	O
Mar	O
2019	O
by	O
the	O
hospital	O
in	O
a	O
message	O
to	O
health	O
authorities	O
.	O

The	O
next	O
day	O
,	O
_Salmonella_	O
Enteritidis	O
was	O
detected	O
in	O
fecal	O
samples	O
.	O

Samples	O
of	O
raw	O
materials	O
and	O
swabs	O
from	O
the	O
kitchen	O
and	O
storage	O
areas	O
were	O
taken	O
.	O

Sanitation	O
and	O
disinfection	O
of	O
all	O
kitchen	O
and	O
storage	O
areas	O
were	O
ordered	O
.	O

The	O
chicken	O
used	O
in	O
the	O
meals	O
was	O
also	O
destroyed	O
.	O

Symptoms	O
of	O
_Salmonella_	O
infection	O
usually	O
appear	O
12	O
to	O
72	O
hours	O
after	O
infection	O
and	O
include	O
fever	O
,	O
abdominal	O
pain	O
,	O
diarrhea	O
,	O
nausea	O
and	O
sometimes	O
vomiting	O
.	O

The	O
illness	O
usually	O
lasts	O
4	O
to	O
7	O
days	O
,	O
and	O
most	O
people	O
recover	O
without	O
treatment	O
.	O

The	O
laboratory	O
analysis	O
at	O
the	O
Institute	O
of	O
Public	O
Health	O
in	O
Ostrava	O
and	O
in	O
the	O
State	O
Veterinary	O
Institute	O
in	O
Olomouc	O
did	O
not	O
confirm	O
_Salmonella_	O
in	O
any	O
sample	O
of	O
frozen	O
chicken	O
available	O
during	O
the	O
investigation	O
.	O

Clinical	O
material	O
from	O
patients	O
was	O
sent	O
to	O
the	O
lab	O
of	O
the	O
Veterinary	O
Research	O
Institute	O
in	O
Brno	O
.	O

the	O

in	O
Zlin	B-City
reported	O
that	O
_	O
S._	O
Enteritidis	O
,	O
identical	O
to	O
the	O
strain	O
grown	O
from	O
clinical	O
cases	O
,	O
was	O
confirmed	O
in	O
a	O
chicken	O
and	O
rice	O
sample	O
.	O

In	O
a	O
statement	O
,	O
officials	O
from	O
the	O
hospital	O
said	O
they	O
had	O
introduced	O
strict	O
measures	O
for	O
food	O
after	O
the	O
_Salmonella_	O
infection	O
,	O
including	O
strengthening	O
controls	O
on	O
the	O
defrosting	O
and	O
cooking	O
of	O
meat	O
so	O
procedures	O
are	O
monitored	O
consistently	O
.	O

Officials	O
said	O
while	O
the	O
hospital	O
can	O
not	O
influence	O
the	O
incidence	O
of	O
_Salmonella_	O
in	O
raw	O
materials	O
supplied	O
to	O
the	O
hospital	O
,	O
they	O
want	O
to	O
focus	O
consistently	O
on	O
the	O
correct	O
procedures	O
for	O
processing	O
.	O

The	O
hospital	O
is	O
also	O
considering	O
buying	O
cameras	O
and	O
putting	O
them	O
in	O
areas	O
where	O
hospital	O
food	O
is	O
being	O
prepared	O
so	O
human	O
error	O
can	O
be	O

in	O

The	O
Minister	O
for	O

and	O

Service	O
(	O

the	O
public	O
after	O
the	O
first	O
known	O
infection	O
of	O
a	O
patient	O
in	O
Ireland	B-Country
with	O

B	I-Virus
from	O
a	O

blood	O

.	O

The	O
IBTS	O
said	O
the	O
infection	O
occurred	O
after	O
the	O
blood	O
donation	O
was	O
made	O
in	O
the	O
``	O
window	O
period	O
''	O
when	O
the	O
virus	O
can	O
not	O
be	O
detected	O
,	O
even	O
by	O
the	O
most	O
sensitive	O
tests	O
available	O
.	O

The	O
case	O
is	O
``	O
not	O
an	O
ongoing	O
patient	O
safety	O
incident	O
''	O
and	O
could	O
not	O
be	O

to	O
a	O
testing	O
failure	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
Minister	O
for	O

Simon	O

.	O

``	O
This	O
is	O
a	O
very	O
rare	O
situation	O
which	O
the	O
IBTS	O
is	O
dealing	O
with	O
in	O
a	O
sensitive	O
manner	O
with	O
the	O
patient	O
impacted	O
.	O
''	O

Dr	O
Stephen	O
Field	O
,	O
IBTS	O
medical	O
and	O
scientific	O
director	O
,	O
described	O
the	O
incident	O
as	O
a	O
``	O
rare	O
,	O
one	O
in	O
2	O
million	O
event	O
''	O
with	O
no	O
implications	O
for	O
blood	O
that	O
will	O
be	O
transfused	O
to	O
patients	O
in	O
the	O
future	O
.	O

He	O
said	O
the	O
IBTS	O
has	O
tested	O
1.2	O
million	O
donations	O
to	O
date	O
and	O
``	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
no	O
other	O
confirmed	O
transfusion	O
transmitted	O
infection	O
of	O
hepatitis	B-Virus
B	I-Virus
.	O
''	O

It	O
is	O
possible	O
for	O
infected	O
blood	O
to	O
pass	O
as	O
negative	O
for	O
a	O
period	O
of	O
about	O
15	O
days	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
Dr	O
Field	O
.	O

Similar	O
cases	O
have	O
arisen	O
in	O
the	O
UK	O
and	O
other	O
countries	O
.	O

The	O
donated	O
blood	O
tested	O
negative	O
for	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
hepatitis	B-Virus
B	I-Virus
before	O
the	O
transfusion	O
,	O
as	O
the	O
virus	O
was	O
not	O
picked	O
up	O
by	O
the	O
screening	O
equipment	O
used	O
.	O

The	O
IBTS	O
said	O
the	O
incident	O
``	O
represents	O
a	O
donation	O
made	O
in	O
the	O
window	O
period	O
when	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
the	O
virus	O
can	O
not	O
be	O
consistently	O
detected	O
even	O
by	O
the	O
most	O
sensitive	O
tests	O
available	O
.	O
''	O

The	O
red	O
blood	O
cells	O
from	O
the	O
donation	O
were	O
transfused	O
into	O
a	O
patient	O
during	O
a	O
medical	O
procedure	O
,	O
which	O
resulted	O
in	O
the	O
patient	O
later	O
contracting	O
hepatitis	B-Virus
B	I-Virus
--	O
a	O
virus	O
that	O
infects	O
the	O
liver	O
.	O

The	O
Health	O
Service	O
Executive	O
became	O
aware	O
of	O
the	O
issue	O
when	O
the	O
original	O
blood	O
donor	O
tested	O
positive	O
for	O
the	O
Hepatitis	B-Virus
B	I-Virus
virus	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
IBTS	O
was	O
informed	O
.	O

The	O
blood	O
transfusion	O
service	O
then	O
carried	O
out	O
a	O
follow	O
up	O
test	O
of	O
an	O
archived	O
sample	O
taken	O
from	O
the	O
blood	O
donor	O
,	O
using	O
the	O
same	O
method	O
and	O
the	O
blood	O
sample	O
came	O
back	O
negative	O
for	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
hepatitis	B-Virus
B	I-Virus
.	O

Following	O
an	O
additional	O
DNA	O
test	O
of	O
the	O
sample	O
results	O
came	O
back	O
positive	O
for	O
the	O
hepatitis	B-Virus
B	I-Virus
virus	O
.	O

The	O
IBTS	O
said	O
the	O
patient	O
is	O
being	O
managed	O
appropriately	O
by	O
a	O
medical	O
team	O
.	O

Most	O
people	O
with	O
normal	O
immune	O
systems	O
will	O
clear	O
the	O
virus	O
,	O
but	O
those	O
infected	O
early	O
in	O
life	O
are	O
more	O
likely	O
to	O
develop	O
chronic	O
infection	O
.	O

Hepatitis	B-Virus
B	I-Virus
virus	O
is	O
transmitted	O
through	O
exposure	O
to	O
infected	O
blood	O
and	O
body	O
fluids	O
such	O
as	O
semen	O
and	O
vaginal	O
secretions	O
.	O

The	O
most	O
common	O
routes	O
of	O
transmission	O
relate	O
to	O
close	O
contact	O
(	O
such	O
as	O
sexual	O
,	O
mother	O
to	O
child	O
,	O
household	O
)	O
with	O
an	O
infected	O
individual	O
,	O
sharing	O
of	O
needles	O
for	O
injecting	O
drug	O
use	O
,	O
or	O
exposure	O
to	O
the	O
virus	O
in	O
a	O
healthcare	O
setting	O
.	O

A	O
9-year-old	O
Georgia	B-Province
boy	O
developed	O
a	O
rare	O
tick-borne	O
infection	O
from	O
a	O
blood	O
transfusion	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
a	O
report	O
of	O
his	O
case	O
.	O

The	O
case	O
is	O
the	O
1st	O
time	O
this	O
infection	O
,	O
called	O
ehrlichiosis	B-Disease
,	O
was	O
spread	O
by	O
a	O
transfusion	O
,	O
said	O
Dr.	O
Joanna	O
Regan	O
of	O
the	O
Centers	O
for	O
Disease	O
Control	O
and	O
Prevention	O
.	O

The	O
bacterial	O
infection	O
,	O
though	O
rare	O
,	O
is	O
serious	O
and	O
can	O
be	O
fatal	O
,	O
Regan	O
said	O
.	O

Ehrlichiosis	B-Disease
can	O
go	O
undetected	O
because	O
routine	O
tests	O
do	O
n't	O
look	O
for	O
it	O
,	O
and	O
many	O
people	O
do	O
not	O
realize	O
they	O
were	O
bitten	O
by	O
a	O
tick	O
.	O

In	O
this	O
case	O
,	O
which	O
occurred	O
during	O
the	O
summer	O
of	O
2011	O
,	O
the	O
boy	O
's	O
condition	O
deteriorated	O
over	O
the	O
course	O
of	O
10	O
days	O
until	O
a	O
pathologist	O
discovered	O
the	O
infection	O
.	O

While	O
ehrlichiosis	B-Disease
is	O
easily	O
treatable	O
with	O
the	O
antibiotic	O
doxycycline	O
,	O
the	O
drug	O
is	O
generally	O
less	O
powerful	O
than	O
other	O
options	O
,	O
so	O
it	O
is	O
often	O
not	O
the	O
1st	O
treatment	O
doctors	O
give	O
when	O
they	O
suspect	O
a	O
patient	O
has	O
some	O
type	O
of	O
infection	O
,	O
Regan	O
said	O
.	O

Indeed	O
,	O
the	O
boy	O
in	O
this	O
case	O
was	O
treated	O
with	O
broad-spectrum	O
antibiotics	O
when	O
he	O
was	O
admitted	O
to	O
the	O
hospital	O
,	O
but	O
he	O
remained	O
ill	O
.	O

The	O
child	O
's	O
family	O
had	O
no	O
reason	O
to	O
suspect	O
a	O
tick-borne	O
infection	O
;	O
he	O
had	O
acute	O
lymphoblastic	O
leukemia	O
and	O
had	O
not	O
been	O
playing	O
outside	O
.	O

The	O
cancer	O
is	O
the	O
most	O
common	O
cancer	O
among	O
children	O
and	O
is	O
highly	O
curable	O
;	O
85	O
percent	O
of	O
children	O
who	O
are	O
treated	O
for	O
the	O
condition	O
are	O
cured	O
.	O

But	O
chemotherapy	O
treatments	O
had	O
left	O
the	O
boy	O
suffering	O
from	O
anemia	O
,	O
and	O
he	O
had	O
received	O
3	O
transfusions	O
in	O
the	O
previous	O
month	O
.	O

He	O
went	O
to	O
his	O
oncologist	O
with	O
fever	O
,	O
vomiting	O
and	O
a	O
rash	O
.	O

``	O
He	O
had	O
classic	O
signs	O
--	O
rash	O
,	O
low	O
white	O
blood	O
cell	O
count	O
,	O
low	O
platelets	O
--	O
but	O
with	O
no	O
possibility	O
of	O
tick	O
exposure	O
,	O
they	O
did	O
n't	O
think	O
of	O
this	O
,	O
''	O
Regan	O
said	O
.	O

``	O
There	O
are	O
many	O
things	O
that	O
were	O
more	O
likely	O
to	O
be	O
making	O
him	O
sick	O
,	O
''	O
such	O
as	O
common	O
bacterial	O
infections	O
,	O
or	O
pneumonia	O
,	O
she	O
said	O
.	O

Finally	O
,	O
a	O
pathologist	O
found	O
the	O
telltale	O
sign	O
of	O
bacteria	O
within	O
the	O
boy	O
's	O
white	O
blood	O
cells	O
.	O

As	O
soon	O
as	O
doctors	O
administered	O
doxycycline	O
,	O
the	O
boy	O
rapidly	O
improved	O
and	O
went	O
home	O
.	O

Health	O
officials	O
tracked	O
down	O
the	O
donors	O
of	O
the	O
3	O
transfusions	O
,	O
and	O
one	O
of	O
those	O
donors	O
reported	O
frequent	O
tick	O
bites	O
.	O

That	O
donor	O
lived	O
in	O
Florida	O
,	O
and	O
further	O
tests	O
showed	O
the	O
person	O
had	O
antibodies	O
against	O
_Ehrlichia_	O
bacteria	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
report	O
.	O

8	O
other	O
people	O
had	O
received	O
transfusions	O
from	O
the	O
donor	O
;	O
3	O
died	O
within	O
a	O
few	O
days	O
of	O
unrelated	O
causes	O
,	O
the	O
other	O
5	O
tested	O
negative	O
for	O
ehrlichiosis	B-Disease
,	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
report	O
.	O

``	O
The	O
donor	O
had	O
no	O
symptoms	O
;	O
that	O
's	O
what	O
made	O
it	O
so	O
difficult	O
,	O
''	O
Regan	O
said	O
.	O

Routine	O
lab	O
tests	O
of	O
the	O
donor	O
's	O
blood	O
appeared	O
normal	O
,	O
although	O
the	O
person	O
reported	O
being	O
bitten	O
by	O
ticks	O
repeatedly	O
,	O
she	O
said	O
.	O

The	O
case	O
shows	O
that	O
doctors	O
should	O
be	O
aware	O
that	O
this	O
infection	O
can	O
be	O
transmitted	O
through	O
blood	O
transfusions	O
.	O

In	O
2011	O
,	O
the	O
CDC	O
reported	O
that	O
162	O
cases	O
of	O
the	O
tick-borne	O
disease	O
babesiosis	O
over	O
3	O
decades	O
were	O
traced	O
to	O
blood	O
transfusions	O
.	O

Lyme	O
disease	O
could	O
also	O
theoretically	O
be	O
transmitted	O
via	O
a	O
transfusion	O
,	O
but	O
no	O
case	O
of	O
this	O
has	O
been	O
reported	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
CDC	O
.	O

Cases	O
of	O
ehrlichiosis	B-Disease
have	O
risen	O
in	O
recent	O
years	O
,	O
from	O
200	O
in	O
2000	O
to	O
740	O
in	O
2010	O
.	O

The	O
condition	O
is	O
fatal	O
in	O
1-2	O
percent	O
of	O
cases	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
CDC	O
.	O

The	O
infection	O
is	O
most	O
common	O
in	O
the	O
southeastern	O
and	O
south-central	O
United	B-Country
States	I-Country
.	O

People	O
should	O
try	O
to	O
avoid	O
tick	O
bites	O
,	O
Regan	O
said	O
.	O

The	O
CDC	O
recommends	O
using	O
repellant	O
products	O
that	O
contain	O
at	O
least	O
20	O
percent	O
DEET	O
,	O
examining	O
the	O
skin	O
for	O
ticks	O
after	O
being	O
outside	O
,	O
and	O
showering	O
soon	O
after	O
outdoor	O
activities	O
.	O

The	O
case	O
report	O
was	O
published	O
on	O
19	O
Mar	O
2013	O
in	O
the	O
journal	O
Clinical	O
Infectious	O
Diseases	O
.	O

A	O
Brooke	O
Army	O
Medical	O
Center	O
staff	O
member	O
was	O
confirmed	O
to	O
have	O
[	O
legionellosis	B-Disease
]	O

[	O

7	O
